getAudioBufferFromURL.name: getAudioBufferFromURL
getAudioBufferFromURL.desc:
Decode and returns the audio buffer of a given audio url or blob uri using Web Audio API.
			(NOTE: This method doesn't works on Safari browser)

Description.0: web url or blob uri of a audio file
Description.1: an instance of Web Audio API AudioContext

getAudioChannelDataFromURL.name: getAudioChannelDataFromURL
getAudioChannelDataFromURL.desc:
Decode and returns the audio channel data from an given audio url or blob uri using Web Audio API.
			(NOTE: This method doesn't works on Safari browser)

Description.0: web url or blob uri of a audio file
Description.1: an instance of Web Audio API AudioContext
Description.2: audio channel number

return.val: decode and returns the audio data as Float32 array for the given channel

audioBufferToMonoSignal.name: audioBufferToMonoSignal
audioBufferToMonoSignal.desc:
Convert an AudioBuffer object to a Mono audio signal array. The audio signal is downmixed
			to mono using essentia MonoMixer algorithm if the audio buffer has 2 channels of audio.
			Throws an expection if the input AudioBuffer object has more than 2 channels of audio.

Description.0: AudioBuffer object decoded from an audio file.

return.val: audio channel data. (downmixed to mono if its stereo signal).

shutdown.name: shutdown
shutdown.desc: Method to shutdown essentia algorithm instance after it's use

reinstantiate.name: reinstantiate
reinstantiate.desc: Method for re-instantiating essentia algorithms instance after using the shutdown method

arrayToVector.name: arrayToVector
arrayToVector.desc: Convert an input JS array into VectorFloat type

vectorToArray.name: vectorToArray
vectorToArray.desc: Convert an input VectorFloat array into typed JS Float32Array

FrameGenerator.name: FrameGenerator
FrameGenerator.desc: Cuts an audio signal data into overlapping frames given frame size and hop size

Description.0: a single channel audio channel data
Description.1: frame size for cutting the audio signal
Description.2: size of overlapping frame

return.val: Returns a 2D vector float of sliced audio frames

MonoMixer.name: MonoMixer
MonoMixer.desc: This algorithm downmixes the signal into a single channel given a stereo signal. It is a wrapper around https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_MonoMixer.html.

Description.0: the left channel of the stereo audio signal
Description.1: the right channel of the stereo audio signal

LoudnessEBUR128.name: LoudnessEBUR128
LoudnessEBUR128.desc: This algorithm computes the EBUR128 loudness descriptors of an audio signal. It is a wrapper around https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_LoudnessEBUR128.html.

Description.0: the left channel of the stereo audio signal
Description.1: the right channel of the stereo audio signal
Description.2: the hop size with which the loudness is computed [s]
Description.3: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]
Description.4: start momentary/short-term loudness estimation at time 0 (zero-centered loudness estimation windows) if true; otherwise start both windows at time 0 (time positions for momentary and short-term values will not be syncronized)

val.loudnessRange: loudness range over an arbitrary long time interval [3] (dB, LU)

AfterMaxToBeforeMaxEnergyRatio.name: AfterMaxToBeforeMaxEnergyRatio
AfterMaxToBeforeMaxEnergyRatio.desc: This algorithm computes the ratio between the pitch energy after the pitch maximum and the pitch energy before the pitch maximum. Sounds having an monotonically ascending pitch or one unique pitch will show a value of (0,1], while sounds having a monotonically descending pitch will show a value of [1,inf). In case there is no energy before the max pitch, the algorithm will return the energy after the maximum pitch. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_AfterMaxToBeforeMaxEnergyRatio.html for more details.

val.afterMaxToBeforeMaxEnergyRatio: the ratio between the pitch energy after the pitch maximum to the pitch energy before the pitch maximum

AllPass.name: AllPass
AllPass.desc: This algorithm implements a IIR all-pass filter of order 1 or 2. Because of its dependence on IIR, IIR's requirements are inherited. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_AllPass.html for more details.

Description.1: the bandwidth of the filter [Hz] (used only for 2nd-order filters)
Description.2: the cutoff frequency for the filter [Hz]
Description.3: the order of the filter
Description.4: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]

AudioOnsetsMarker.name: AudioOnsetsMarker
AudioOnsetsMarker.desc: This algorithm creates a wave file in which a given audio signal is mixed with a series of time onsets. The sonification of the onsets can be heard as beeps, or as short white noise pulses if configured to do so. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_AudioOnsetsMarker.html for more details.

Description.1: the list of onset locations [s]
Description.2: the sampling rate of the output signal [Hz]
Description.3: the type of sound to be added on the event

val.signal: the input signal mixed with bursts at onset locations

AutoCorrelation.name: AutoCorrelation
AutoCorrelation.desc:
This algorithm computes the autocorrelation vector of a signal.
			It uses the version most commonly used in signal processing, which doesn't remove the mean from the observations.
			Using the 'generalized' option this algorithm computes autocorrelation as described in [3]. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_AutoCorrelation.html for more details.

Description.1: factor at which FFT magnitude is compressed (only used if 'generalized' is set to true, see [3])
Description.2: bool value to indicate whether to compute the 'generalized' autocorrelation as described in [3]
Description.3: type of normalization to compute: either 'standard' (default) or 'unbiased'

BFCC.name: BFCC
BFCC.desc:
This algorithm computes the bark-frequency cepstrum coefficients of a spectrum. Bark bands and their subsequent usage in cepstral analysis have shown to be useful in percussive content [1, 2]
			This algorithm is implemented using the Bark scaling approach in the Rastamat version of the MFCC algorithm and in a similar manner to the MFCC-FB40 default specs: Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_BFCC.html for more details.

Description.1: the DCT type
Description.2: the upper bound of the frequency range [Hz]
Description.3: the size of input spectrum
Description.4: the liftering coefficient. Use '0' to bypass it
Description.5: logarithmic compression type. Use 'dbpow' if working with power and 'dbamp' if working with magnitudes
Description.6: the lower bound of the frequency range [Hz]
Description.7: 'unit_max' makes the vertex of all the triangles equal to 1, 'unit_sum' makes the area of all the triangles equal to 1
Description.8: the number of bark bands in the filter
Description.9: the number of output cepstrum coefficients
Description.10: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]
Description.12: type of weighting function for determining triangle area

BPF.name: BPF
BPF.desc: This algorithm implements a break point function which linearly interpolates between discrete xy-coordinates to construct a continuous function. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_BPF.html for more details.

Description.1: the x-coordinates of the points forming the break-point function (the points must be arranged in ascending order and cannot contain duplicates)
Description.2: the y-coordinates of the points forming the break-point function

BandPass.name: BandPass
BandPass.desc: This algorithm implements a 2nd order IIR band-pass filter. Because of its dependence on IIR, IIR's requirements are inherited. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_BandPass.html for more details.

Description.1: the bandwidth of the filter [Hz]
Description.2: the cutoff frequency for the filter [Hz]
Description.3: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]

BandReject.name: BandReject
BandReject.desc: This algorithm implements a 2nd order IIR band-reject filter. Because of its dependence on IIR, IIR's requirements are inherited. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_BandReject.html for more details.

Description.1: the bandwidth of the filter [Hz]
Description.2: the cutoff frequency for the filter [Hz]
Description.3: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]

BarkBands.name: BarkBands
BarkBands.desc: This algorithm computes energy in Bark bands of a spectrum. The band frequencies are: [0.0, 50.0, 100.0, 150.0, 200.0, 300.0, 400.0, 510.0, 630.0, 770.0, 920.0, 1080.0, 1270.0, 1480.0, 1720.0, 2000.0, 2320.0, 2700.0, 3150.0, 3700.0, 4400.0, 5300.0, 6400.0, 7700.0, 9500.0, 12000.0, 15500.0, 20500.0, 27000.0]. The first two Bark bands [0,100] and [100,200] have been split in half for better resolution (because of an observed better performance in beat detection). For each bark band the power-spectrum (mag-squared) is summed. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_BarkBands.html for more details.

Description.1: the number of desired barkbands
Description.2: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]

val.bands: the energy of the bark bands

BeatTrackerDegara.name: BeatTrackerDegara
BeatTrackerDegara.desc: This algorithm estimates the beat positions given an input signal. It computes 'complex spectral difference' onset detection function and utilizes the beat tracking algorithm (TempoTapDegara) to extract beats [1]. The algorithm works with the optimized settings of 2048/1024 frame/hop size for the computation of the detection function, with its posterior x2 resampling.) While it has a lower accuracy than BeatTrackerMultifeature (see the evaluation results in [2]), its computational speed is significantly higher, which makes reasonable to apply this algorithm for batch processings of large amounts of audio signals. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_BeatTrackerDegara.html for more details.

Description.1: the fastest tempo to detect [bpm]
Description.2: the slowest tempo to detect [bpm]

BeatTrackerMultiFeature.name: BeatTrackerMultiFeature
BeatTrackerMultiFeature.desc:
This algorithm estimates the beat positions given an input signal. It computes a number of onset detection functions and estimates beat location candidates from them using TempoTapDegara algorithm. Thereafter the best candidates are selected using TempoTapMaxAgreement. The employed detection functions, and the optimal frame/hop sizes used for their computation are:
			- complex spectral difference (see 'complex' method in OnsetDetection algorithm, 2048/1024 with posterior x2 upsample or the detection function)
			- energy flux (see 'rms' method in OnsetDetection algorithm, the same settings)
			- spectral flux in Mel-frequency bands (see 'melflux' method in OnsetDetection algorithm, the same settings)
			- beat emphasis function (see 'beat_emphasis' method in OnsetDetectionGlobal algorithm, 2048/512)
			- spectral flux between histogrammed spectrum frames, measured by the modified information gain (see 'infogain' method in OnsetDetectionGlobal algorithm, 2048/512) Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_BeatTrackerMultiFeature.html for more details.

Description.1: the fastest tempo to detect [bpm]
Description.2: the slowest tempo to detect [bpm]

Beatogram.name: Beatogram
Beatogram.desc:
This algorithm filters the loudness matrix given by BeatsLoudness algorithm in order to keep only the most salient beat band representation.
			This algorithm has been found to be useful for estimating time signatures. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_Beatogram.html for more details.

Description.1: matrix of loudness ratios at each band and beat
Description.2: number of beats for dynamic filtering

BeatsLoudness.name: BeatsLoudness
BeatsLoudness.desc: This algorithm computes the spectrum energy of beats in an audio signal given their positions. The energy is computed both on the whole frequency range and for each of the specified frequency bands. See the SingleBeatLoudness algorithm for a more detailed explanation. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_BeatsLoudness.html for more details.

Description.1: the duration of the window in which the beat will be restricted [s]
Description.2: the duration of the window in which to look for the beginning of the beat (centered around the positions in 'beats') [s]
Description.3: the list of beat positions (each position is in seconds)
Description.4: the list of bands to compute energy ratios [Hz
Description.5: the audio sampling rate [Hz]

val.loudness: the beat's energy in the whole spectrum
val.loudnessBandRatio: the ratio of the beat's energy on each frequency band

BinaryOperator.name: BinaryOperator
BinaryOperator.desc:
This algorithm performs basic arithmetical operations element by element given two arrays.
			Note:
			- using this algorithm in streaming mode can cause diamond shape graphs which have not been tested with the current scheduler. There is NO GUARANTEE of its correct work for diamond shape graphs.
			- for y<0, x/y is invalid Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_BinaryOperator.html for more details.

Description.1: the second operand input array
Description.2: the type of the binary operator to apply to the input arrays

val.array: the array containing the result of binary operation

BinaryOperatorStream.name: BinaryOperatorStream
BinaryOperatorStream.desc:
This algorithm performs basic arithmetical operations element by element given two arrays.
			Note:
			- using this algorithm in streaming mode can cause diamond shape graphs which have not been tested with the current scheduler. There is NO GUARANTEE of its correct work for diamond shape graphs.
			- for y<0, x/y is invalid Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_BinaryOperatorStream.html for more details.

Description.1: the second operand input array
Description.2: the type of the binary operator to apply to the input arrays

val.array: the array containing the result of binary operation

BpmHistogramDescriptors.name: BpmHistogramDescriptors
BpmHistogramDescriptors.desc:
This algorithm computes beats per minute histogram and its statistics for the highest and second highest peak.
			Note: histogram vector contains occurance frequency for each bpm value, 0-th element corresponds to 0 bpm value. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_BpmHistogramDescriptors.html for more details.

val.secondPeakBPM: value for the second highest peak [bpm]
val.secondPeakWeight: weight of the second highest peak
val.secondPeakSpread: spread of the second highest peak

BpmRubato.name: BpmRubato
BpmRubato.desc: This algorithm extracts the locations of large tempo changes from a list of beat ticks. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_BpmRubato.html for more details.

Description.1: time for the longest constant tempo region inside a rubato region [s]
Description.2: time for the shortest constant tempo region from one tempo region to another [s]
Description.3: minimum tempo deviation to look for

val.rubatoStart: list of timestamps where the start of a rubato region was detected [s]
val.rubatoStop: list of timestamps where the end of a rubato region was detected [s]

CentralMoments.name: CentralMoments
CentralMoments.desc: This algorithm extracts the 0th, 1st, 2nd, 3rd and 4th central moments of an array. It returns a 5-tuple in which the index corresponds to the order of the moment. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_CentralMoments.html for more details.

Description.1: compute central moments considering array values as a probability density function over array index or as sample points of a distribution
Description.2: the range of the input array, used for normalizing the results in the 'pdf' mode

val.centralMoments: the central moments of the input array

Centroid.name: Centroid
Centroid.desc: This algorithm computes the centroid of an array. The centroid is normalized to a specified range. This algorithm can be used to compute spectral centroid or temporal centroid. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_Centroid.html for more details.

Description.1: the range of the input array, used for normalizing the results

ChordsDescriptors.name: ChordsDescriptors
ChordsDescriptors.desc:
Given a chord progression this algorithm describes it by means of key, scale, histogram, and rate of change.
			Note:
			- chordsHistogram indexes follow the circle of fifths order, while being shifted to the input key and scale
			- key and scale are taken from the most frequent chord. In the case where multiple chords are equally frequent, the chord is hierarchically chosen from the circle of fifths.
			- chords should follow this name convention <A-G>[<#/b><m>] (i.e. C, C# or C#m are valid chords). Chord names not fitting this convention will throw an exception. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_ChordsDescriptors.html for more details.

Description.1: the key of the whole song, from A to G
Description.2: the scale of the whole song (major or minor)

val.chordsNumberRate: the ratio of different chords from the total number of chords in the progression
val.chordsChangesRate: the rate at which chords change in the progression
val.chordsKey: the most frequent chord of the progression
val.chordsScale: the scale of the most frequent chord of the progression (either 'major' or 'minor')

ChordsDetection.name: ChordsDetection
ChordsDetection.desc: This algorithm estimates chords given an input sequence of harmonic pitch class profiles (HPCPs). It finds the best matching major or minor triad and outputs the result as a string (e.g. A#, Bm, G#m, C). This algorithm uses the Sharp versions of each Flatted note (i.e. Bb -> A#). Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_ChordsDetection.html for more details.

Description.0: the pitch class profile from which to detect the chord
Description.1: the hop size with which the input PCPs were computed
Description.2: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]
Description.3: the size of the window on which to estimate the chords [s]

val.chords: the resulting chords, from A to G

ChordsDetectionBeats.name: ChordsDetectionBeats
ChordsDetectionBeats.desc:
This algorithm estimates chords using pitch profile classes on segments between beats. It is similar to ChordsDetection algorithm, but the chords are estimated on audio segments between each pair of consecutive beats. For each segment the estimation is done based on a chroma (HPCP) vector characterizing it, which can be computed by two methods:
			- 'interbeat_median', each resulting chroma vector component is a median of all the component values in the segment
			- 'starting_beat', chroma vector is sampled from the start of the segment (that is, its starting beat position) using its first frame. It makes sense if chroma is preliminary smoothed. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_ChordsDetectionBeats.html for more details.

Description.0: the pitch class profile from which to detect the chord
Description.1: the list of beat positions (in seconds)
Description.2: method of calculating singleton chroma for interbeat interval
Description.3: the hop size with which the input PCPs were computed
Description.4: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]

val.chords: the resulting chords, from A to G

ChromaCrossSimilarity.name: ChromaCrossSimilarity
ChromaCrossSimilarity.desc: This algorithm computes a binary cross similarity matrix from two chromagam feature vectors of a query and reference song. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_ChromaCrossSimilarity.html for more details.

Description.0: frame-wise chromagram of the query song (e.g., a HPCP)
Description.1: frame-wise chromagram of the reference song (e.g., a HPCP)
Description.2: maximum percent of distance values to consider as similar in each row and each column
Description.3: number of input frames to stack together and treat as a feature vector for similarity computation. Choose 'frameStackSize=1' to use the original input frames without stacking
Description.4: stride size to form a stack of frames (e.g., 'frameStackStride'=1 to use consecutive frames; 'frameStackStride'=2 for using every second frame)
Description.5: number of circular shifts to be checked for Optimal Transposition Index [1]
Description.6: whether to transpose the key of the reference song to the query song by Optimal Transposition Index [1]
Description.7: whether to use the OTI-based chroma binary similarity method [3]
Description.8: whether to accumulate the input 'queryFeature' in the euclidean similarity matrix calculation on each compute() method call

val.csm: 2D binary cross-similarity matrix of the query and reference features

Chromagram.name: Chromagram
Chromagram.desc:
This algorithm computes the Constant-Q chromagram using FFT. See ConstantQ algorithm for more details.
			Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_Chromagram.html for more details.

Description.1: number of bins per octave
Description.2: minimum frequency [Hz]
Description.3: minimum size allowed for frequency kernels
Description.4: normalize type
Description.5: number of frequency bins, starting at minFrequency
Description.6: FFT sampling rate [Hz]
Description.7: filters scale. Larger values use longer windows
Description.8: bins whose magnitude is below this quantile are discarded
Description.9: the window type, which can be 'hamming', 'hann', 'triangular', 'square' or 'blackmanharrisXX'
Description.10: a boolean value that enables zero-phase windowing. Input audio frames should be windowed with the same phase mode

ClickDetector.name: ClickDetector
ClickDetector.desc: This algorithm detects the locations of impulsive noises (clicks and pops) on the input audio frame. It relies on LPC coefficients to inverse-filter the audio in order to attenuate the stationary part and enhance the prediction error (or excitation noise)[1]. After this, a matched filter is used to further enhance the impulsive peaks. The detection threshold is obtained from a robust estimate of the excitation noise power [2] plus a parametric gain value. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_ClickDetector.html for more details.

Description.1: 'detectionThreshold' the threshold is based on the instant power of the noisy excitation signal plus detectionThreshold dBs
Description.2: the expected size of the input audio signal (this is an optional parameter to optimize memory allocation)
Description.3: hop size used for the analysis. This parameter must be set correctly as it cannot be obtained from the input data
Description.4: scalar giving the number of LPCs to use
Description.5: the noisy excitation is clipped to 'powerEstimationThreshold' times its median.
Description.6: sample rate used for the analysis
Description.7: threshold to skip silent frames

Clipper.name: Clipper
Clipper.desc: This algorithm clips the input signal to fit its values into a specified interval. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_Clipper.html for more details.

Description.1: the maximum value above which the signal will be clipped
Description.2: the minimum value below which the signal will be clipped

val.signal: the output signal with the added noise

CoverSongSimilarity.name: CoverSongSimilarity
CoverSongSimilarity.desc: This algorithm computes a cover song similiarity measure from a binary cross similarity matrix input between two chroma vectors of a query and reference song using various alignment constraints of smith-waterman local-alignment algorithm. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_CoverSongSimilarity.html for more details.

Description.0: a 2D binary cross-similarity matrix between two audio chroma vectors (query vs reference song) (refer 'ChromaCrossSimilarity' algorithm').
Description.1: choose either one of the given local-alignment constraints for smith-waterman algorithm as described in [2] or [3] respectively.
Description.2: penalty for disruption extension
Description.3: penalty for disruption onset
Description.4: choose the type of distance. By default the algorithm outputs a asymmetric disctance which is obtained by normalising the maximum score in the alignment score matrix with length of reference song

val.scoreMatrix: a 2D smith-waterman alignment score matrix from the input binary cross-similarity matrix
val.distance: cover song similarity distance between the query and reference song from the input similarity matrix. Either 'asymmetric' (as described in [2]) or 'symmetric' (maximum score in the alignment score matrix).

Crest.name: Crest
Crest.desc: This algorithm computes the crest of an array. The crest is defined as the ratio between the maximum value and the arithmetic mean of an array. Typically it is used on the magnitude spectrum. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_Crest.html for more details.

Description.0: the input array (cannot contain negative values, and must be non-empty)

val.crest: the crest of the input array

CrossCorrelation.name: CrossCorrelation
CrossCorrelation.desc: This algorithm computes the cross-correlation vector of two signals. It accepts 2 parameters, minLag and maxLag which define the range of the computation of the innerproduct. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_CrossCorrelation.html for more details.

Description.1: the second input array
Description.2: the maximum lag to be computed between the two vectors
Description.3: the minimum lag to be computed between the two vectors

val.crossCorrelation: the cross-correlation vector between the two input arrays (its size is equal to maxLag - minLag + 1)

CrossSimilarityMatrix.name: CrossSimilarityMatrix
CrossSimilarityMatrix.desc: This algorithm computes a euclidean cross-similarity matrix of two sequences of frame features. Similarity values can be optionally binarized Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_CrossSimilarityMatrix.html for more details.

Description.0: input frame features of the query song (e.g., a chromagram)
Description.1: input frame features of the reference song (e.g., a chromagram)
Description.2: whether to binarize the euclidean cross-similarity matrix
Description.3: maximum percent of distance values to consider as similar in each row and each column
Description.4: number of input frames to stack together and treat as a feature vector for similarity computation. Choose 'frameStackSize=1' to use the original input frames without stacking
Description.5: stride size to form a stack of frames (e.g., 'frameStackStride'=1 to use consecutive frames; 'frameStackStride'=2 for using every second frame)

val.csm: 2D cross-similarity matrix of two input frame sequences (query vs reference)

CubicSpline.name: CubicSpline
CubicSpline.desc:
Computes the second derivatives of a piecewise cubic spline.
			The input value, i.e. the point at which the spline is to be evaluated typically should be between xPoints[0] and xPoints[size-1]. If the value lies outside this range, extrapolation is used.
			Regarding [left/right] boundary condition flag parameters:
			- 0: the cubic spline should be a quadratic over the first interval
			- 1: the first derivative at the [left/right] endpoint should be [left/right]BoundaryFlag
			- 2: the second derivative at the [left/right] endpoint should be [left/right]BoundaryFlag
			References:
			[1] Spline interpolation - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia,
			http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spline_interpolation Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_CubicSpline.html for more details.

Description.1: type of boundary condition for the left boundary
Description.2: the value to be used in the left boundary, when leftBoundaryFlag is 1 or 2
Description.3: type of boundary condition for the right boundary
Description.4: the value to be used in the right boundary, when rightBoundaryFlag is 1 or 2
Description.5: the x-coordinates where data is specified (the points must be arranged in ascending order and cannot contain duplicates)
Description.6: the y-coordinates to be interpolated (i.e. the known data)

val.y: the value of the spline at x
val.dy: the first derivative of the spline at x
val.ddy: the second derivative of the spline at x

DCRemoval.name: DCRemoval
DCRemoval.desc: This algorithm removes the DC offset from a signal using a 1st order IIR highpass filter. Because of its dependence on IIR, IIR's requirements are inherited. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_DCRemoval.html for more details.

Description.1: the cutoff frequency for the filter [Hz]
Description.2: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]

val.signal: the filtered signal, with the DC component removed

DCT.name: DCT
DCT.desc:
This algorithm computes the Discrete Cosine Transform of an array.
			It uses the DCT-II form, with the 1/sqrt(2) scaling factor for the first coefficient. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_DCT.html for more details.

Description.1: the DCT type
Description.2: the size of the input array
Description.3: the liftering coefficient. Use '0' to bypass it
Description.4: the number of output coefficients

val.dct: the discrete cosine transform of the input array

Danceability.name: Danceability
Danceability.desc: This algorithm estimates danceability of a given audio signal. The algorithm is derived from Detrended Fluctuation Analysis (DFA) described in [1]. The parameters minTau and maxTau are used to define the range of time over which DFA will be performed. The output of this algorithm is the danceability of the audio signal. These values usually range from 0 to 3 (higher values meaning more danceable). Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_Danceability.html for more details.

Description.1: maximum segment length to consider [ms]
Description.2: minimum segment length to consider [ms]
Description.3: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]
Description.4: multiplier to increment from min to max tau

val.danceability: the danceability value. Normal values range from 0 to ~3. The higher, the more danceable.
val.dfa: the DFA exponent vector for considered segment length (tau) values

Decrease.name: Decrease
Decrease.desc:
This algorithm computes the decrease of an array defined as the linear regression coefficient. The range parameter is used to normalize the result. For a spectral centroid, the range should be equal to Nyquist and for an audio centroid the range should be equal to (audiosize - 1) / samplerate.
			The size of the input array must be at least two elements for "decrease" to be computed, otherwise an exception is thrown.
			References:
			[1] Least Squares Fitting -- from Wolfram MathWorld,
			http://mathworld.wolfram.com/LeastSquaresFitting.html Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_Decrease.html for more details.

Description.1: the range of the input array, used for normalizing the results

val.decrease: the decrease of the input array

Derivative.name: Derivative
Derivative.desc: This algorithm returns the first-order derivative of an input signal. That is, for each input value it returns the value minus the previous one. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_Derivative.html for more details.

val.signal: the derivative of the input signal

DerivativeSFX.name: DerivativeSFX
DerivativeSFX.desc: This algorithm computes two descriptors that are based on the derivative of a signal envelope. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_DerivativeSFX.html for more details.

val.derAvAfterMax: the weighted average of the derivative after the maximum amplitude
val.maxDerBeforeMax: the maximum derivative before the maximum amplitude

DiscontinuityDetector.name: DiscontinuityDetector
DiscontinuityDetector.desc: This algorithm uses LPC and some heuristics to detect discontinuities in an audio signal. [1]. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_DiscontinuityDetector.html for more details.

Description.1: 'detectionThreshold' times the standard deviation plus the median of the frame is used as detection threshold
Description.2: threshold in dB to detect silent subframes
Description.3: the expected size of the input audio signal (this is an optional parameter to optimize memory allocation)
Description.4: hop size used for the analysis. This parameter must be set correctly as it cannot be obtained from the input data
Description.5: scalar giving the size of the median filter window. Must be odd
Description.6: scalar giving the number of LPCs to use
Description.7: threshold to skip silent frames
Description.8: size of the window used to compute silent subframes

val.discontinuityLocations: the index of the detected discontinuities (if any)
val.discontinuityAmplitudes: the peak values of the prediction error for the discontinuities (if any)

Dissonance.name: Dissonance
Dissonance.desc:
This algorithm computes the sensory dissonance of an audio signal given its spectral peaks. Sensory dissonance (to be distinguished from musical or theoretical dissonance) measures perceptual roughness of the sound and is based on the roughness of its spectral peaks. Given the spectral peaks, the algorithm estimates total dissonance by summing up the normalized dissonance values for each pair of peaks. These values are computed using dissonance curves, which define dissonace between two spectral peaks according to their frequency and amplitude relations. The dissonance curves are based on perceptual experiments conducted in [1].
			Exceptions are thrown when the size of the input vectors are not equal or if input frequencies are not ordered ascendantly
			References:
			[1] R. Plomp and W. J. M. Levelt, "Tonal Consonance and Critical
			Bandwidth," The Journal of the Acoustical Society of America, vol. 38,
			no. 4, pp. 548560, 1965. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_Dissonance.html for more details.

Description.0: the frequencies of the spectral peaks (must be sorted by frequency)
Description.1: the magnitudes of the spectral peaks (must be sorted by frequency

val.dissonance: the dissonance of the audio signal (0 meaning completely consonant, and 1 meaning completely dissonant)

DistributionShape.name: DistributionShape
DistributionShape.desc:
This algorithm computes the spread (variance), skewness and kurtosis of an array given its central moments. The extracted features are good indicators of the shape of the distribution. For the required input see CentralMoments algorithm.
			The size of the input array must be at least 5. An exception will be thrown otherwise. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_DistributionShape.html for more details.

Description.0: the central moments of a distribution

Duration.name: Duration
Duration.desc: This algorithm outputs the total duration of an audio signal. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_Duration.html for more details.

Description.1: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]

DynamicComplexity.name: DynamicComplexity
DynamicComplexity.desc: This algorithm computes the dynamic complexity defined as the average absolute deviation from the global loudness level estimate on the dB scale. It is related to the dynamic range and to the amount of fluctuation in loudness present in a recording. Silence at the beginning and at the end of a track are ignored in the computation in order not to deteriorate the results. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_DynamicComplexity.html for more details.

Description.1: the frame size [s]
Description.2: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]

ERBBands.name: ERBBands
ERBBands.desc: This algorithm computes energies/magnitudes in ERB bands of a spectrum. The Equivalent Rectangular Bandwidth (ERB) scale is used. The algorithm applies a frequency domain filterbank using gammatone filters. Adapted from matlab code in:  D. P. W. Ellis (2009). 'Gammatone-like spectrograms', web resource [1]. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_ERBBands.html for more details.

Description.1: an upper-bound limit for the frequencies to be included in the bands
Description.2: the size of the spectrum
Description.3: a lower-bound limit for the frequencies to be included in the bands
Description.4: the number of output bands
Description.5: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]
Description.6: use magnitude or power spectrum
Description.7: filter width with respect to ERB

EffectiveDuration.name: EffectiveDuration
EffectiveDuration.desc:
This algorithm computes the effective duration of an envelope signal. The effective duration is a measure of the time the signal is perceptually meaningful. This is approximated by the time the envelope is above or equal to a given threshold and is above the -90db noise floor. This measure allows to distinguish percussive sounds from sustained sounds but depends on the signal length.
			By default, this algorithm uses 40% of the envelope maximum as the threshold which is suited for short sounds. Note, that the 0% thresold corresponds to the duration of signal above -90db noise floor, while the 100% thresold corresponds to the number of times the envelope takes its maximum value.
			References:
			[1] G. Peeters, "A large set of audio features for sound description
			(similarity and classification) in the CUIDADO project," CUIDADO I.S.T.
			Project Report, 2004 Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_EffectiveDuration.html for more details.

Description.1: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]
Description.2: the ratio of the envelope maximum to be used as the threshold

val.effectiveDuration: the effective duration of the signal [s]

Energy.name: Energy
Energy.desc: This algorithm computes the energy of an array. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_Energy.html for more details.

val.energy: the energy of the input array

EnergyBand.name: EnergyBand
EnergyBand.desc:
This algorithm computes energy in a given frequency band of a spectrum including both start and stop cutoff frequencies.
			Note that exceptions will be thrown when input spectrum is empty and if startCutoffFrequency is greater than stopCutoffFrequency. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_EnergyBand.html for more details.

Description.1: the audio sampling rate [Hz]
Description.2: the start frequency from which to sum the energy [Hz]
Description.3: the stop frequency to which to sum the energy [Hz]

val.energyBand: the energy in the frequency band

EnergyBandRatio.name: EnergyBandRatio
EnergyBandRatio.desc: This algorithm computes the ratio of the spectral energy in the range [startFrequency, stopFrequency] over the total energy. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_EnergyBandRatio.html for more details.

Description.1: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]
Description.2: the frequency from which to start summing the energy [Hz]
Description.3: the frequency up to which to sum the energy [Hz]

val.energyBandRatio: the energy ratio of the specified band over the total energy

Entropy.name: Entropy
Entropy.desc: This algorithm computes the Shannon entropy of an array. Entropy can be used to quantify the peakiness of a distribution. This has been used for voiced/unvoiced decision in automatic speech recognition.  Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_Entropy.html for more details.

Description.0: the input array (cannot contain negative values, and must be non-empty)

val.entropy: the entropy of the input array

Envelope.name: Envelope
Envelope.desc: This algorithm computes the envelope of a signal by applying a non-symmetric lowpass filter on a signal. By default it rectifies the signal, but that is optional. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_Envelope.html for more details.

Description.1: whether to apply rectification (envelope based on the absolute value of signal)
Description.2: the attack time of the first order lowpass in the attack phase [ms]
Description.3: the release time of the first order lowpass in the release phase [ms]
Description.4: the audio sampling rate [Hz]

val.signal: the resulting envelope of the signal

EqualLoudness.name: EqualLoudness
EqualLoudness.desc: This algorithm implements an equal-loudness filter. The human ear does not perceive sounds of all frequencies as having equal loudness, and to account for this, the signal is filtered by an inverted approximation of the equal-loudness curves. Technically, the filter is a cascade of a 10th order Yulewalk filter with a 2nd order Butterworth high pass filter. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_EqualLoudness.html for more details.

Description.1: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]

Flatness.name: Flatness
Flatness.desc: This algorithm computes the flatness of an array, which is defined as the ratio between the geometric mean and the arithmetic mean. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_Flatness.html for more details.

val.flatness: the flatness (ratio between the geometric and the arithmetic mean of the input array)

FlatnessDB.name: FlatnessDB
FlatnessDB.desc: This algorithm computes the flatness of an array, which is defined as the ratio between the geometric mean and the arithmetic mean converted to dB scale. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_FlatnessDB.html for more details.

FlatnessSFX.name: FlatnessSFX
FlatnessSFX.desc: This algorithm calculates the flatness coefficient of a signal envelope. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_FlatnessSFX.html for more details.

Flux.name: Flux
Flux.desc: This algorithm computes the spectral flux of a spectrum. Flux is defined as the L2-norm [1] or L1-norm [2] of the difference between two consecutive frames of the magnitude spectrum. The frames have to be of the same size in order to yield a meaningful result. The default L2-norm is used more commonly. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_Flux.html for more details.

Description.1: half-rectify the differences in each spectrum bin
Description.2: the norm to use for difference computation

val.flux: the spectral flux of the input spectrum

FrameCutter.name: FrameCutter
FrameCutter.desc: This algorithm slices the input buffer into frames. It returns a frame of a constant size and jumps a constant amount of samples forward in the buffer on every compute() call until no more frames can be extracted; empty frame vectors are returned afterwards. Incomplete frames (frames starting before the beginning of the input buffer or going past its end) are zero-padded or dropped according to the "validFrameThresholdRatio" parameter. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_FrameCutter.html for more details.

Description.0: the buffer from which to read data
Description.1: the output frame size
Description.2: the hop size between frames
Description.3: whether the beginning of the last frame should reach the end of file. Only applicable if startFromZero is true
Description.4: whether to start the first frame at time 0 (centered at frameSize/2) if true, or -frameSize/2 otherwise (zero-centered)
Description.5: frames smaller than this ratio will be discarded, those larger will be zero-padded to a full frame (i.e. a value of 0 will never discard frames and a value of 1 will only keep frames that are of length 'frameSize')

FrameToReal.name: FrameToReal
FrameToReal.desc: This algorithm converts a sequence of input audio signal frames into a sequence of audio samples. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_FrameToReal.html for more details.

Description.1: the frame size for computing the overlap-add process
Description.2: the hop size with which the overlap-add function is computed

FrequencyBands.name: FrequencyBands
FrequencyBands.desc: This algorithm computes energy in rectangular frequency bands of a spectrum. The bands are non-overlapping. For each band the power-spectrum (mag-squared) is summed. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_FrequencyBands.html for more details.

Description.0: the input spectrum (must be greater than size one)
Description.1: list of frequency ranges in to which the spectrum is divided (these must be in ascending order and connot contain duplicates)
Description.2: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]

GFCC.name: GFCC
GFCC.desc: This algorithm computes the Gammatone-frequency cepstral coefficients of a spectrum. This is an equivalent of MFCCs, but using a gammatone filterbank (ERBBands) scaled on an Equivalent Rectangular Bandwidth (ERB) scale. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_GFCC.html for more details.

Description.1: the DCT type
Description.2: the upper bound of the frequency range [Hz]
Description.3: the size of input spectrum
Description.4: logarithmic compression type. Use 'dbpow' if working with power and 'dbamp' if working with magnitudes
Description.5: the lower bound of the frequency range [Hz]
Description.6: the number of bands in the filter
Description.7: the number of output cepstrum coefficients
Description.8: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]
Description.9: silence threshold for computing log-energy bands
Description.10: use magnitude or power spectrum

GapsDetector.name: GapsDetector
GapsDetector.desc:
This algorithm uses energy and time thresholds to detect gaps in the waveform. A median filter is used to remove spurious silent samples. The power of a small audio region before the detected gaps (prepower) is thresholded to detect intentional pauses as described in [1]. This technique isextended to the region after the gap.
			The algorithm was designed for a framewise use and returns the start and end timestamps related to the first frame processed. Call configure() or reset() in order to restart the count. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_GapsDetector.html for more details.

Description.1: the attack time of the first order lowpass in the attack phase [ms]
Description.2: frame size used for the analysis. Should match the input frame size. Otherwise, an exception will be thrown
Description.3: hop size used for the analysis
Description.4: scalar giving the size of the median filter window. Must be odd
Description.5: time of the maximum gap duration [ms]
Description.6: time of the minimum gap duration [ms]
Description.7: time for the postpower calculation [ms]
Description.8: prepower threshold [dB].
Description.9: time for the prepower calculation [ms]
Description.10: the release time of the first order lowpass in the release phase [ms]
Description.11: sample rate used for the analysis

val.starts: the start indexes of the detected gaps (if any) in seconds
val.ends: the end indexes of the detected gaps (if any) in seconds

GeometricMean.name: GeometricMean
GeometricMean.desc: This algorithm computes the geometric mean of an array of positive values. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_GeometricMean.html for more details.

val.geometricMean: the geometric mean of the input array

HFC.name: HFC
HFC.desc:
This algorithm computes the High Frequency Content of a spectrum. It can be computed according to the following techniques:
			- 'Masri' (default) which does: sum |X(n)|^2*k,
			- 'Jensen' which does: sum |X(n)|*k^2
			- 'Brossier' which does: sum |X(n)|*k Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_HFC.html for more details.

Description.1: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]
Description.2: the type of HFC coefficient to be computed

HPCP.name: HPCP
HPCP.desc: Computes a Harmonic Pitch Class Profile (HPCP) from the spectral peaks of a signal. HPCP is a k*12 dimensional vector which represents the intensities of the twelve (k==1) semitone pitch classes (corresponsing to notes from A to G#), or subdivisions of these (k>1). Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_HPCP.html for more details.

Description.0: the frequencies of the spectral peaks [Hz]
Description.1: the magnitudes of the spectral peaks
Description.2: enables whether to use a band preset
Description.3: the split frequency for low and high bands, not used if bandPreset is false [Hz]
Description.4: number of harmonics for frequency contribution, 0 indicates exclusive fundamental frequency contribution
Description.5: the maximum frequency that contributes to the HPCP [Hz] (the difference between the max and split frequencies must not be less than 200.0 Hz)
Description.6: whether to shift the HPCP vector so that the maximum peak is at index 0
Description.7: the minimum frequency that contributes to the HPCP [Hz] (the difference between the min and split frequencies must not be less than 200.0 Hz)
Description.8: apply non-linear post-processing to the output (use with normalized='unitMax'). Boosts values close to 1, decreases values close to 0.
Description.9: whether to normalize the HPCP vector
Description.10: the reference frequency for semitone index calculation, corresponding to A3 [Hz]
Description.11: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]
Description.12: the size of the output HPCP (must be a positive nonzero multiple of 12)
Description.13: type of weighting function for determining frequency contribution
Description.14: the size, in semitones, of the window used for the weighting

val.hpcp: the resulting harmonic pitch class profile

HarmonicBpm.name: HarmonicBpm
HarmonicBpm.desc:
This algorithm extracts bpms that are harmonically related to the tempo given by the 'bpm' parameter.
			The algorithm assumes a certain bpm is harmonically related to parameter bpm, when the greatest common divisor between both bpms is greater than threshold.
			The 'tolerance' parameter is needed in order to consider if two bpms are related. For instance, 120, 122 and 236 may be related or not depending on how much tolerance is given Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_HarmonicBpm.html for more details.

Description.1: the bpm used to find its harmonics
Description.2: bpm threshold below which greatest common divisors are discarded
Description.3: percentage tolerance to consider two bpms are equal or equal to a harmonic

val.harmonicBpms: a list of bpms which are harmonically related to the bpm parameter

HarmonicPeaks.name: HarmonicPeaks
HarmonicPeaks.desc:
This algorithm finds the harmonic peaks of a signal given its spectral peaks and its fundamental frequency.
			Note:
			- "tolerance" parameter defines the allowed fixed deviation from ideal harmonics, being a percentage over the F0. For example: if the F0 is 100Hz you may decide to allow a deviation of 20%, that is a fixed deviation of 20Hz; for the harmonic series it is: [180-220], [280-320], [380-420], etc.
			- If "pitch" is zero, it means its value is unknown, or the sound is unpitched, and in that case the HarmonicPeaks algorithm returns an empty vector.
			- The output frequency and magnitude vectors are of size "maxHarmonics". If a particular harmonic was not found among spectral peaks, its ideal frequency value is output together with 0 magnitude.
			This algorithm is intended to receive its "frequencies" and "magnitudes" inputs from the SpectralPeaks algorithm.
			- When input vectors differ in size or are empty, an exception is thrown. Input vectors must be ordered by ascending frequency excluding DC components and not contain duplicates, otherwise an exception is thrown. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_HarmonicPeaks.html for more details.

Description.0: the frequencies of the spectral peaks [Hz] (ascending order)
Description.1: the magnitudes of the spectral peaks (ascending frequency order)
Description.2: an estimate of the fundamental frequency of the signal [Hz]
Description.3: the number of harmonics to return including F0
Description.4: the allowed ratio deviation from ideal harmonics

HighPass.name: HighPass
HighPass.desc: This algorithm implements a 1st order IIR high-pass filter. Because of its dependence on IIR, IIR's requirements are inherited. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_HighPass.html for more details.

Description.1: the cutoff frequency for the filter [Hz]
Description.2: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]

HighResolutionFeatures.name: HighResolutionFeatures
HighResolutionFeatures.desc:
This algorithm computes high-resolution chroma features from an HPCP vector. The vector's size must be a multiple of 12 and it is recommended that it be larger than 120. In otherwords, the HPCP's resolution should be 10 Cents or more.
			The high-resolution features being computed are: Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_HighResolutionFeatures.html for more details.

Description.1: maximum number of HPCP peaks to consider when calculating outputs

val.equalTemperedDeviation: measure of the deviation of HPCP local maxima with respect to equal-tempered bins
val.nonTemperedEnergyRatio: ratio between the energy on non-tempered bins and the total energy
val.nonTemperedPeaksEnergyRatio: ratio between the energy on non-tempered peaks and the total energy

Histogram.name: Histogram
Histogram.desc: This algorithm computes a histogram. Values outside the range are ignored Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_Histogram.html for more details.

Description.1: the max value of the histogram
Description.2: the min value of the histogram
Description.3: the normalization setting.
Description.4: the number of bins

val.histogram: the values in the equally-spaced bins
val.binEdges: the edges of the equally-spaced bins. Size is _histogram.size() + 1

HprModelAnal.name: HprModelAnal
HprModelAnal.desc: This algorithm computes the harmonic plus residual model analysis. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_HprModelAnal.html for more details.

Description.1: external pitch input [Hz].
Description.2: the size of the internal FFT size (full spectrum size)
Description.3: minimum frequency deviation at 0Hz
Description.4: slope increase of minimum frequency deviation
Description.5: slope increase of minimum frequency deviation
Description.6: the hop size between frames
Description.7: peaks below this given threshold are not outputted
Description.8: the maximum frequency of the range to evaluate [Hz]
Description.9: the maximum number of returned peaks
Description.10: maximum number of sines per frame
Description.11: the minimum frequency of the range to evaluate [Hz]
Description.12: maximum number of harmonics per frame
Description.13: the ordering type of the outputted peaks (ascending by frequency or descending by magnitude)
Description.14: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]
Description.15: decimation factor used for the stochastic approximation

val.frequencies: the frequencies of the sinusoidal peaks [Hz]
val.magnitudes: the magnitudes of the sinusoidal peaks
val.phases: the phases of the sinusoidal peaks

HpsModelAnal.name: HpsModelAnal
HpsModelAnal.desc: This algorithm computes the harmonic plus stochastic model analysis.  Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_HpsModelAnal.html for more details.

Description.1: external pitch input [Hz].
Description.2: the size of the internal FFT size (full spectrum size)
Description.3: minimum frequency deviation at 0Hz
Description.4: slope increase of minimum frequency deviation
Description.5: slope increase of minimum frequency deviation
Description.6: the hop size between frames
Description.7: peaks below this given threshold are not outputted
Description.8: the maximum frequency of the range to evaluate [Hz]
Description.9: the maximum number of returned peaks
Description.10: maximum number of sines per frame
Description.11: the minimum frequency of the range to evaluate [Hz]
Description.12: maximum number of harmonics per frame
Description.13: the ordering type of the outputted peaks (ascending by frequency or descending by magnitude)
Description.14: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]
Description.15: decimation factor used for the stochastic approximation

val.frequencies: the frequencies of the sinusoidal peaks [Hz]
val.magnitudes: the magnitudes of the sinusoidal peaks
val.phases: the phases of the sinusoidal peaks

IDCT.name: IDCT
IDCT.desc:
This algorithm computes the Inverse Discrete Cosine Transform of an array.
			It can be configured to perform the inverse DCT-II form, with the 1/sqrt(2) scaling factor for the first coefficient or the inverse DCT-III form based on the HTK implementation. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_IDCT.html for more details.

Description.1: the DCT type
Description.2: the size of the input array
Description.3: the liftering coefficient. Use '0' to bypass it
Description.4: the number of output coefficients

val.idct: the inverse cosine transform of the input array

IIR.name: IIR
IIR.desc: This algorithm implements a standard IIR filter. It filters the data in the input vector with the filter described by parameter vectors 'numerator' and 'denominator' to create the output filtered vector. In the litterature, the numerator is often referred to as the 'B' coefficients and the denominator as the 'A' coefficients. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_IIR.html for more details.

Description.1: the list of coefficients of the denominator. Often referred to as the A coefficient vector.
Description.2: the list of coefficients of the numerator. Often referred to as the B coefficient vector.

Inharmonicity.name: Inharmonicity
Inharmonicity.desc: This algorithm calculates the inharmonicity of a signal given its spectral peaks. The inharmonicity value is computed as an energy weighted divergence of the spectral components from their closest multiple of the fundamental frequency. The fundamental frequency is taken as the first spectral peak from the input. The inharmonicity value ranges from 0 (purely harmonic signal) to 1 (inharmonic signal). Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_Inharmonicity.html for more details.

Description.0: the frequencies of the harmonic peaks [Hz] (in ascending order)
Description.1: the magnitudes of the harmonic peaks (in frequency ascending order

val.inharmonicity: the inharmonicity of the audio signal

InstantPower.name: InstantPower
InstantPower.desc: This algorithm computes the instant power of an array. That is, the energy of the array over its size. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_InstantPower.html for more details.

val.power: the instant power of the input array

Intensity.name: Intensity
Intensity.desc: This algorithm classifies the input audio signal as either relaxed (-1), moderate (0), or aggressive (1). Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_Intensity.html for more details.

Description.1: the input audio sampling rate [Hz]

Key.name: Key
Key.desc: This algorithm computes key estimate given a pitch class profile (HPCP). The algorithm was severely adapted and changed from the original implementation for readability and speed. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_Key.html for more details.

Description.1: number of harmonics that should contribute to the polyphonic profile (1 only considers the fundamental harmonic)
Description.2: number of array elements used to represent a semitone times 12 (this parameter is only a hint, during computation, the size of the input PCP is used instead)
Description.3: the type of polyphic profile to use for correlation calculation
Description.4: value of the slope of the exponential harmonic contribution to the polyphonic profile
Description.5: use a third profile called 'majmin' for ambiguous tracks [4]. Only avalable for the edma, bgate and braw profiles
Description.6: enables the use of polyphonic profiles to define key profiles (this includes the contributions from triads as well as pitch harmonics)
Description.7: consider only the 3 main triad chords of the key (T, D, SD) to build the polyphonic profiles

val.key: the estimated key, from A to G
val.scale: the scale of the key (major or minor)
val.strength: the strength of the estimated key
val.firstToSecondRelativeStrength: the relative strength difference between the best estimate and second best estimate of the key

KeyExtractor.name: KeyExtractor
KeyExtractor.desc: This algorithm extracts key/scale for an audio signal. It computes HPCP frames for the input signal and applies key estimation using the Key algorithm. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_KeyExtractor.html for more details.

Description.1: shifts a pcp to the nearest tempered bin
Description.2: the framesize for computing tonal features
Description.3: the hopsize for computing tonal features
Description.4: the size of the output HPCP (must be a positive nonzero multiple of 12)
Description.5: max frequency to apply whitening to [Hz]
Description.6: the maximum number of spectral peaks
Description.7: min frequency to apply whitening to [Hz]
Description.8: pcp bins below this value are set to 0
Description.9: the type of polyphic profile to use for correlation calculation
Description.10: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]
Description.11: the threshold for the spectral peaks
Description.12: the tuning frequency of the input signal
Description.13: type of weighting function for determining frequency contribution
Description.14: the window type, which can be 'hamming', 'hann', 'triangular', 'square' or 'blackmanharrisXX'

LPC.name: LPC
LPC.desc: This algorithm computes Linear Predictive Coefficients and associated reflection coefficients of a signal. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_LPC.html for more details.

Description.1: the order of the LPC analysis (typically [8,14])
Description.2: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]
Description.3: the type of LPC (regular or warped)

Larm.name: Larm
Larm.desc: This algorithm estimates the long-term loudness of an audio signal. The LARM model is based on the asymmetrical low-pass filtering of the Peak Program Meter (PPM), combined with Revised Low-frequency B-weighting (RLB) and power mean calculations. LARM has shown to be a reliable and objective loudness estimate of music and speech. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_Larm.html for more details.

Description.1: the attack time of the first order lowpass in the attack phase [ms]
Description.2: the power used for averaging
Description.3: the release time of the first order lowpass in the release phase [ms]
Description.4: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]

Leq.name: Leq
Leq.desc:
This algorithm computes the Equivalent sound level (Leq) of an audio signal. The Leq measure can be derived from the Revised Low-frequency B-weighting (RLB) or from the raw signal as described in [1]. If the signal contains no energy, Leq defaults to essentias definition of silence which is -90dB.
			This algorithm will throw an exception on empty input. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_Leq.html for more details.

LevelExtractor.name: LevelExtractor
LevelExtractor.desc: This algorithm extracts the loudness of an audio signal in frames using Loudness algorithm. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_LevelExtractor.html for more details.

Description.1: frame size to compute loudness
Description.2: hop size to compute loudness

LogAttackTime.name: LogAttackTime
LogAttackTime.desc: This algorithm computes the log (base 10) of the attack time of a signal envelope. The attack time is defined as the time duration from when the sound becomes perceptually audible to when it reaches its maximum intensity. By default, the start of the attack is estimated as the point where the signal envelope reaches 20% of its maximum value in order to account for possible noise presence. Also by default, the end of the attack is estimated as as the point where the signal envelope has reached 90% of its maximum value, in order to account for the possibility that the max value occurres after the logAttack, as in trumpet sounds. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_LogAttackTime.html for more details.

Description.0: the input signal envelope (must be non-empty)
Description.1: the audio sampling rate [Hz]
Description.2: the percentage of the input signal envelope at which the starting point of the attack is considered
Description.3: the percentage of the input signal envelope at which the ending point of the attack is considered

val.logAttackTime: the log (base 10) of the attack time [log10(s)]

LogSpectrum.name: LogSpectrum
LogSpectrum.desc: This algorithm computes spectrum with logarithmically distributed frequency bins. This code is ported from NNLS Chroma [1, 2].This algorithm also returns a local tuning that is retrieved for input frame and a global tuning that is updated with a moving average. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_LogSpectrum.html for more details.

Description.1: bins per semitone
Description.2: the input frame size of the spectrum vector
Description.3: this removes low-frequency noise - useful in quiet recordings
Description.4: the input sample rate

LoopBpmConfidence.name: LoopBpmConfidence
LoopBpmConfidence.desc: This algorithm takes an audio signal and a BPM estimate for that signal and predicts the reliability of the BPM estimate in a value from 0 to 1. The audio signal is assumed to be a musical loop with constant tempo. The confidence returned is based on comparing the duration of the signal with multiples of the BPM estimate (see [1] for more details). Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_LoopBpmConfidence.html for more details.

Description.1: estimated BPM for the audio signal
Description.2: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]

val.confidence: confidence value for the BPM estimation

LoopBpmEstimator.name: LoopBpmEstimator
LoopBpmEstimator.desc: This algorithm estimates the BPM of audio loops. It internally uses PercivalBpmEstimator algorithm to produce a BPM estimate and LoopBpmConfidence to asses the reliability of the estimate. If the provided estimate is below the given confidenceThreshold, the algorithm outputs a BPM 0.0, otherwise it outputs the estimated BPM. For more details on the BPM estimation method and the confidence measure please check the used algorithms. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_LoopBpmEstimator.html for more details.

Description.1: confidence threshold below which bpm estimate will be considered unreliable

val.bpm: the estimated bpm (will be 0 if unsure)

Loudness.name: Loudness
Loudness.desc: This algorithm computes the loudness of an audio signal defined by Steven's power law. It computes loudness as the energy of the signal raised to the power of 0.67. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_Loudness.html for more details.

val.loudness: the loudness of the input signal

LoudnessVickers.name: LoudnessVickers
LoudnessVickers.desc: This algorithm computes Vickers's loudness of an audio signal. Currently, this algorithm only works for signals with a 44100Hz sampling rate. This algorithm is meant to be given frames of audio as input (not entire audio signals). The algorithm described in the paper performs a weighted average of the loudness value computed for each of the given frames, this step is left as a post processing step and is not performed by this algorithm. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_LoudnessVickers.html for more details.

Description.1: the audio sampling rate of the input signal which is used to create the weight vector [Hz] (currently, this algorithm only works on signals with a sampling rate of 44100Hz)

LowLevelSpectralEqloudExtractor.name: LowLevelSpectralEqloudExtractor
LowLevelSpectralEqloudExtractor.desc: This algorithm extracts a set of level spectral features for which it is recommended to apply a preliminary equal-loudness filter over an input audio signal (according to the internal evaluations conducted at Music Technology Group). To this end, you are expected to provide the output of EqualLoudness algorithm as an input for this algorithm. Still, you are free to provide an unprocessed audio input in the case you want to compute these features without equal-loudness filter. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_LowLevelSpectralEqloudExtractor.html for more details.

Description.1: the frame size for computing low level features
Description.2: the hop size for computing low level features
Description.3: the audio sampling rate

LowLevelSpectralExtractor.name: LowLevelSpectralExtractor
LowLevelSpectralExtractor.desc: This algorithm extracts all low-level spectral features, which do not require an equal-loudness filter for their computation, from an audio signal Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_LowLevelSpectralExtractor.html for more details.

Description.1: the frame size for computing low level features
Description.2: the hop size for computing low level features
Description.3: the audio sampling rate

val.barkbands: spectral energy at each bark band. See BarkBands alogithm
val.barkbands_kurtosis: kurtosis from bark bands. See DistributionShape algorithm documentation
val.barkbands_skewness: skewness from bark bands. See DistributionShape algorithm documentation
val.barkbands_spread: spread from barkbands. See DistributionShape algorithm documentation
val.spectral_energyband_low: Energy in band (20,150] Hz. See EnergyBand algorithm documentation
val.spectral_energyband_middle_low: Energy in band (150,800] Hz.See EnergyBand algorithm documentation
val.spectral_energyband_middle_high: Energy in band (800,4000] Hz. See EnergyBand algorithm documentation
val.spectral_energyband_high: Energy in band (4000,20000] Hz. See EnergyBand algorithm documentation

LowPass.name: LowPass
LowPass.desc:
This algorithm implements a 1st order IIR low-pass filter. Because of its dependence on IIR, IIR's requirements are inherited.
			References:
			[1] U. Zlzer, DAFX - Digital Audio Effects, p. 40,
			John Wiley & Sons, 2002 Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_LowPass.html for more details.

Description.1: the cutoff frequency for the filter [Hz]
Description.2: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]

MFCC.name: MFCC
MFCC.desc:
This algorithm computes the mel-frequency cepstrum coefficients of a spectrum. As there is no standard implementation, the MFCC-FB40 is used by default:
			- filterbank of 40 bands from 0 to 11000Hz
			- take the log value of the spectrum energy in each mel band. Bands energy values below silence threshold will be clipped to its value before computing log-energies
			- DCT of the 40 bands down to 13 mel coefficients
			There is a paper describing various MFCC implementations [1]. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_MFCC.html for more details.

Description.1: the DCT type
Description.2: the upper bound of the frequency range [Hz]
Description.3: the size of input spectrum
Description.4: the liftering coefficient. Use '0' to bypass it
Description.5: logarithmic compression type. Use 'dbpow' if working with power and 'dbamp' if working with magnitudes
Description.6: the lower bound of the frequency range [Hz]
Description.7: spectrum bin weights to use for each mel band: 'unit_max' to make each mel band vertex equal to 1, 'unit_sum' to make each mel band area equal to 1 summing the actual weights of spectrum bins, 'unit_area' to make each triangle mel band area equal to 1 normalizing the weights of each triangle by its bandwidth
Description.8: the number of mel-bands in the filter
Description.9: the number of output mel coefficients
Description.10: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]
Description.11: silence threshold for computing log-energy bands
Description.13: The scale implementation type: 'htkMel' scale from the HTK toolkit [2, 3] (default) or 'slaneyMel' scale from the Auditory toolbox [4]
Description.14: type of weighting function for determining triangle area

MaxFilter.name: MaxFilter
MaxFilter.desc: This algorithm implements a maximum filter for 1d signal using van Herk/Gil-Werman (HGW) algorithm. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_MaxFilter.html for more details.

Description.1: use casual filter (window is behind current element otherwise it is centered around)
Description.2: the window size, has to be odd if the window is centered

MaxMagFreq.name: MaxMagFreq
MaxMagFreq.desc:
This algorithm computes the frequency with the largest magnitude in a spectrum.
			Note that a spectrum must contain at least two elements otherwise an exception is thrown Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_MaxMagFreq.html for more details.

Description.0: the input spectrum (must have more than 1 element)
Description.1: the audio sampling rate [Hz]

val.maxMagFreq: the frequency with the largest magnitude [Hz]

MaxToTotal.name: MaxToTotal
MaxToTotal.desc: This algorithm computes the ratio between the index of the maximum value of the envelope of a signal and the total length of the envelope. This ratio shows how much the maximum amplitude is off-center. Its value is close to 0 if the maximum is close to the beginning (e.g. Decrescendo or Impulsive sounds), close to 0.5 if it is close to the middle (e.g. Delta sounds) and close to 1 if it is close to the end of the sound (e.g. Crescendo sounds). This algorithm is intended to be fed by the output of the Envelope algorithm Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_MaxToTotal.html for more details.

val.maxToTotal: the maximum amplitude position to total length ratio

Mean.name: Mean
Mean.desc: This algorithm computes the mean of an array. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_Mean.html for more details.

val.mean: the mean of the input array

Median.name: Median
Median.desc: This algorithm computes the median of an array. When there is an odd number of numbers, the median is simply the middle number. For example, the median of 2, 4, and 7 is 4. When there is an even number of numbers, the median is the mean of the two middle numbers. Thus, the median of the numbers 2, 4, 7, 12 is (4+7)/2 = 5.5. See [1] for more info. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_Median.html for more details.

val.median: the median of the input array

MedianFilter.name: MedianFilter
MedianFilter.desc: This algorithm computes the median filtered version of the input signal giving the kernel size as detailed in [1]. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_MedianFilter.html for more details.

Description.1: scalar giving the size of the median filter window. Must be odd

MelBands.name: MelBands
MelBands.desc: This algorithm computes energy in mel bands of a spectrum. It applies a frequency-domain filterbank (MFCC FB-40, [1]), which consists of equal area triangular filters spaced according to the mel scale. The filterbank is normalized in such a way that the sum of coefficients for every filter equals one. It is recommended that the input "spectrum" be calculated by the Spectrum algorithm. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_MelBands.html for more details.

Description.1: an upper-bound limit for the frequencies to be included in the bands
Description.2: the size of the spectrum
Description.3: compute log-energies (log10 (1 + energy))
Description.4: a lower-bound limit for the frequencies to be included in the bands
Description.5: spectrum bin weights to use for each mel band: 'unit_max' to make each mel band vertex equal to 1, 'unit_sum' to make each mel band area equal to 1 summing the actual weights of spectrum bins, 'unit_area' to make each triangle mel band area equal to 1 normalizing the weights of each triangle by its bandwidth
Description.6: the number of output bands
Description.7: the sample rate
Description.8: 'power' to output squared units, 'magnitude' to keep it as the input
Description.9: The scale implementation type: 'htkMel' scale from the HTK toolkit [2, 3] (default) or 'slaneyMel' scale from the Auditory toolbox [4]
Description.10: type of weighting function for determining triangle area

Meter.name: Meter
Meter.desc: This algorithm estimates the time signature of a given beatogram by finding the highest correlation between beats. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_Meter.html for more details.

MinMax.name: MinMax
MinMax.desc:
This algorithm calculates the minimum or maximum value of an array.
			If the array has more than one minimum or maximum value, the index of the first one is returned Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_MinMax.html for more details.

Description.1: the type of the operation

val.real: the minimum or maximum of the input array, according to the type parameter

MinToTotal.name: MinToTotal
MinToTotal.desc: This algorithm computes the ratio between the index of the minimum value of the envelope of a signal and the total length of the envelope. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_MinToTotal.html for more details.

val.minToTotal: the minimum amplitude position to total length ratio

MovingAverage.name: MovingAverage
MovingAverage.desc: This algorithm implements a FIR Moving Average filter. Because of its dependece on IIR, IIR's requirements are inherited. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_MovingAverage.html for more details.

Description.1: the size of the window [audio samples]

MultiPitchKlapuri.name: MultiPitchKlapuri
MultiPitchKlapuri.desc:
This algorithm estimates multiple pitch values corresponding to the melodic lines present in a polyphonic music signal (for example, string quartet, piano). This implementation is based on the algorithm in [1]: In each frame, a set of possible fundamental frequency candidates is extracted based on the principle of harmonic summation. In an optimization stage, the number of harmonic sources (polyphony) is estimated and the final set of fundamental frequencies determined. In contrast to the pich salience function proposed in [2], this implementation uses the pitch salience function described in [1].
			The output is a vector for each frame containing the estimated melody pitch values. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_MultiPitchKlapuri.html for more details.

Description.1: salience function bin resolution [cents]
Description.2: the frame size for computing pitch saliecnce
Description.3: harmonic weighting parameter (weight decay ratio between two consequent harmonics, =1 for no decay)
Description.4: the hop size with which the pitch salience function was computed
Description.5: magnitude compression parameter for the salience function (=0 for maximum compression, =1 for no compression)
Description.6: spectral peak magnitude threshold (maximum allowed difference from the highest peak in dBs)
Description.7: the maximum allowed frequency for salience function peaks (ignore peaks above) [Hz]
Description.8: the minimum allowed frequency for salience function peaks (ignore peaks below) [Hz]
Description.9: number of considered harmonics
Description.10: the reference frequency for Hertz to cent convertion [Hz], corresponding to the 0th cent bin
Description.11: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]

MultiPitchMelodia.name: MultiPitchMelodia
MultiPitchMelodia.desc: This algorithm estimates multiple fundamental frequency contours from an audio signal. It is a multi pitch version of the MELODIA algorithm described in [1]. While the algorithm is originally designed to extract melody in polyphonic music, this implementation is adapted for multiple sources. The approach is based on the creation and characterization of pitch contours, time continuous sequences of pitch candidates grouped using auditory streaming cues. To this end, PitchSalienceFunction, PitchSalienceFunctionPeaks, PitchContours, and PitchContoursMonoMelody algorithms are employed. It is strongly advised to use the default parameter values which are optimized according to [1] (where further details are provided) except for minFrequency, maxFrequency, and voicingTolerance, which will depend on your application. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_MultiPitchMelodia.html for more details.

Description.1: salience function bin resolution [cents]
Description.2: number of iterations for the octave errors / pitch outlier filtering process
Description.3: the frame size for computing pitch saliecnce
Description.4: estimate pitch for non-voiced segments by using non-salient contours when no salient ones are present in a frame
