Description.5: harmonic weighting parameter (weight decay ratio between two consequent harmonics, =1 for no decay)
Description.6: the hop size with which the pitch salience function was computed
Description.7: magnitude compression parameter for the salience function (=0 for maximum compression, =1 for no compression)
Description.8: spectral peak magnitude threshold (maximum allowed difference from the highest peak in dBs)
Description.9: the minimum allowed frequency for salience function peaks (ignore contours with peaks above) [Hz]
Description.10: the minimum allowed contour duration [ms]
Description.11: the minimum allowed frequency for salience function peaks (ignore contours with peaks below) [Hz]
Description.13: allowed deviation below the peak salience mean over all frames (fraction of the standard deviation)
Description.14: per-frame salience threshold factor (fraction of the highest peak salience in a frame)
Description.15: pitch continuity cue (maximum allowed pitch change during 1 ms time period) [cents]
Description.16: the reference frequency for Hertz to cent convertion [Hz], corresponding to the 0th cent bin
Description.17: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]
Description.18: time continuity cue (the maximum allowed gap duration for a pitch contour) [ms]

Multiplexer.name: Multiplexer
Multiplexer.desc: This algorithm returns a single vector from a given number of real values and/or frames. Frames from different inputs are multiplexed onto a single stream in an alternating fashion. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_Multiplexer.html for more details.

Description.0: the number of inputs of type Real to multiplex
Description.1: the number of inputs of type vector to multiplex

val.data: the frame containing the input values and/or input frames

NNLSChroma.name: NNLSChroma
NNLSChroma.desc:
This algorithm extracts treble and bass chromagrams from a sequence of log-frequency spectrum frames.
			On this representation, two processing steps are performed:
			-tuning, after which each centre bin (i.e. bin 2, 5, 8, ...) corresponds to a semitone, even if the tuning of the piece deviates from 440 Hz standard pitch.
			-running standardisation: subtraction of the running mean, division by the running standard deviation. This has a spectral whitening effect.
			This code is ported from NNLS Chroma [1, 2]. To achieve similar results follow this processing chain:
			frame slicing with sample rate = 44100, frame size = 16384, hop size = 2048 -> Windowing with Hann and no normalization -> Spectrum -> LogSpectrum. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_NNLSChroma.html for more details.

Description.1: mean tuning frames
Description.2: local tuning frames
Description.3: determines whether or how the chromagrams are normalised
Description.4: the input frame size of the spectrum vector
Description.5: the input sample rate
Description.6: the shape of the notes in the NNLS dictionary
Description.7: determines how much the log-frequency spectrum is whitened
Description.8: local uses a local average for tuning, global uses all audio frames. Local tuning is only advisable when the tuning is likely to change over the audio
Description.9: toggle between NNLS approximate transcription and linear spectral mapping

val.semitoneSpectrum: a spectral representation with one bin per semitone
val.bassChromagram: a 12-dimensional chromagram, restricted to the bass range
val.chromagram: a 12-dimensional chromagram, restricted with mid-range emphasis

NoiseAdder.name: NoiseAdder
NoiseAdder.desc: This algorithm adds noise to an input signal. The average energy of the noise in dB is defined by the level parameter, and is generated using the Mersenne Twister random number generator. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_NoiseAdder.html for more details.

Description.1: if true, 0 is used as the seed for generating random values
Description.2: power level of the noise generator [dB]

val.signal: the output signal with the added noise

NoiseBurstDetector.name: NoiseBurstDetector
NoiseBurstDetector.desc: This algorithm detects noise bursts in the waveform by thresholding  the peaks of the second derivative. The threshold is computed using an Exponential Moving Average filter over the RMS of the second derivative of the input frame. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_NoiseBurstDetector.html for more details.

Description.1: alpha coefficient for the Exponential Moving Average threshold estimation.
Description.2: threshold to skip silent frames
Description.3: factor to control the dynamic theshold

NoveltyCurve.name: NoveltyCurve
NoveltyCurve.desc: This algorithm computes the "novelty curve" (Grosche & Mller, 2009) onset detection function. The algorithm expects as an input a frame-wise sequence of frequency-bands energies or spectrum magnitudes as originally proposed in [1] (see FrequencyBands and Spectrum algorithms). Novelty in each band (or frequency bin) is computed as a derivative between log-compressed energy (magnitude) values in consequent frames. The overall novelty value is then computed as a weighted sum that can be configured using 'weightCurve' parameter. The resulting novelty curve can be used for beat tracking and onset detection (see BpmHistogram and Onsets). Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_NoveltyCurve.html for more details.

Description.1: the sampling rate of the input audio
Description.2: whether to normalize each band's energy
Description.3: vector containing the weights for each frequency band. Only if weightCurveType==supplied
Description.4: the type of weighting to be used for the bands novelty

val.novelty: the novelty curve as a single vector

NoveltyCurveFixedBpmEstimator.name: NoveltyCurveFixedBpmEstimator
NoveltyCurveFixedBpmEstimator.desc: This algorithm outputs a histogram of the most probable bpms assuming the signal has constant tempo given the novelty curve. This algorithm is based on the autocorrelation of the novelty curve (see NoveltyCurve algorithm) and should only be used for signals that have a constant tempo or as a first tempo estimator to be used in conjunction with other algorithms such as BpmHistogram.It is a simplified version of the algorithm described in [1] as, in order to predict the best BPM candidate,  it computes autocorrelation of the entire novelty curve instead of analyzing it on frames and histogramming the peaks over frames. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_NoveltyCurveFixedBpmEstimator.html for more details.

Description.0: the novelty curve of the audio signal
Description.1: the hopSize used to computeh the novelty curve from the original signal
Description.2: the maximum bpm to look for
Description.3: the minimum bpm to look for
Description.4: the sampling rate original audio signal [Hz]
Description.5: tolerance (in percentage) for considering bpms to be equal

val.bpms: the bpm candidates sorted by magnitude
val.amplitudes: the magnitude of each bpm candidate

OddToEvenHarmonicEnergyRatio.name: OddToEvenHarmonicEnergyRatio
OddToEvenHarmonicEnergyRatio.desc:
This algorithm computes the ratio between a signal's odd and even harmonic energy given the signal's harmonic peaks. The odd to even harmonic energy ratio is a measure allowing to distinguish odd-harmonic-energy predominant sounds (such as from a clarinet) from equally important even-harmonic-energy sounds (such as from a trumpet). The required harmonic frequencies and magnitudes can be computed by the HarmonicPeaks algorithm.
			In the case when the even energy is zero, which may happen when only even harmonics where found or when only one peak was found, the algorithm outputs the maximum real number possible. Therefore, this algorithm should be used in conjunction with the harmonic peaks algorithm.
			If no peaks are supplied, the algorithm outputs a value of one, assuming either the spectrum was flat or it was silent. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_OddToEvenHarmonicEnergyRatio.html for more details.

Description.0: the frequencies of the harmonic peaks (at least two frequencies in frequency ascending order)
Description.1: the magnitudes of the harmonic peaks (at least two magnitudes in frequency ascending order)

val.oddToEvenHarmonicEnergyRatio: the ratio between the odd and even harmonic energies of the given harmonic peaks

OnsetDetection.name: OnsetDetection
OnsetDetection.desc:
This algorithm computes various onset detection functions. The output of this algorithm should be post-processed in order to determine whether the frame contains an onset or not. Namely, it could be fed to the Onsets algorithm. It is recommended that the input "spectrum" is generated by the Spectrum algorithm.
			Four methods are available:
			- 'HFC', the High Frequency Content detection function which accurately detects percussive events (see HFC algorithm for details).
			- 'complex', the Complex-Domain spectral difference function [1] taking into account changes in magnitude and phase. It emphasizes note onsets either as a result of significant change in energy in the magnitude spectrum, and/or a deviation from the expected phase values in the phase spectrum, caused by a change in pitch.
			- 'complex_phase', the simplified Complex-Domain spectral difference function [2] taking into account phase changes, weighted by magnitude. TODO:It reacts better on tonal sounds such as bowed string, but tends to over-detect percussive events.
			- 'flux', the Spectral Flux detection function which characterizes changes in magnitude spectrum. See Flux algorithm for details.
			- 'melflux', the spectral difference function, similar to spectral flux, but using half-rectified energy changes in Mel-frequency bands of the spectrum [3].
			- 'rms', the difference function, measuring the half-rectified change of the RMS of the magnitude spectrum (i.e., measuring overall energy flux) [4]. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_OnsetDetection.html for more details.

Description.1: the phase vector corresponding to this spectrum (used only by the "complex" method)
Description.2: the method used for onset detection
Description.3: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]

val.onsetDetection: the value of the detection function in the current frame

OnsetDetectionGlobal.name: OnsetDetectionGlobal
OnsetDetectionGlobal.desc:
This algorithm computes various onset detection functions. Detection values are computed frame-wisely given an input signal. The output of this algorithm should be post-processed in order to determine whether the frame contains an onset or not. Namely, it could be fed to the Onsets algorithm.
			The following method are available:
			- 'infogain', the spectral difference measured by the modified information gain [1]. For each frame, it accounts for energy change in between preceding and consecutive frames, histogrammed together, in order to suppress short-term variations on frame-by-frame basis.
			- 'beat_emphasis', the beat emphasis function [1]. This function is a linear combination of onset detection functions (complex spectral differences) in a number of sub-bands, weighted by their beat strength computed over the entire input signal.
			Note:
			- 'infogain' onset detection has been optimized for the default sampleRate=44100Hz, frameSize=2048, hopSize=512.
			- 'beat_emphasis' is optimized for a fixed resolution of 11.6ms, which corresponds to the default sampleRate=44100Hz, frameSize=1024, hopSize=512.
			Optimal performance of beat detection with TempoTapDegara is not guaranteed for other settings. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_OnsetDetectionGlobal.html for more details.

Description.1: the frame size for computing onset detection function
Description.2: the hop size for computing onset detection function
Description.3: the method used for onset detection
Description.4: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]

val.onsetDetections: the frame-wise values of the detection function

OnsetRate.name: OnsetRate
OnsetRate.desc:
This algorithm computes the number of onsets per second and their position in time for an audio signal. Onset detection functions are computed using both high frequency content and complex-domain methods available in OnsetDetection algorithm. See OnsetDetection for more information.
			Please note that due to a dependence on the Onsets algorithm, this algorithm is only valid for audio signals with a sampling rate of 44100Hz.
			This algorithm throws an exception if the input signal is empty. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_OnsetRate.html for more details.

val.onsetRate: the number of onsets per second

OverlapAdd.name: OverlapAdd
OverlapAdd.desc: This algorithm returns the output of an overlap-add process for a sequence of frames of an audio signal. It considers that the input audio frames are windowed audio signals. Giving the size of the frame and the hop size, overlapping and adding consecutive frames will produce a continuous signal. A normalization gain can be passed as a parameter. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_OverlapAdd.html for more details.

Description.1: the frame size for computing the overlap-add process
Description.2: the normalization gain that scales the output signal. Useful for IFFT output
Description.3: the hop size with which the overlap-add function is computed

val.signal: the output overlap-add audio signal frame

PeakDetection.name: PeakDetection
PeakDetection.desc:
This algorithm detects local maxima (peaks) in an array. The algorithm finds positive slopes and detects a peak when the slope changes sign and the peak is above the threshold.
			It optionally interpolates using parabolic curve fitting.
			When two consecutive peaks are closer than the minPeakDistance parameter, the smallest one is discarded. A value of 0 bypasses this feature. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_PeakDetection.html for more details.

Description.1: boolean flag to enable interpolation
Description.2: the maximum number of returned peaks
Description.3: the maximum value of the range to evaluate
Description.4: minimum distance between consecutive peaks (0 to bypass this feature)
Description.5: the minimum value of the range to evaluate
Description.6: the ordering type of the output peaks (ascending by position or descending by value)
Description.7: the input range
Description.8: peaks below this given threshold are not output

PercivalBpmEstimator.name: PercivalBpmEstimator
PercivalBpmEstimator.desc: This algorithm estimates the tempo in beats per minute (BPM) from an input signal as described in [1]. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_PercivalBpmEstimator.html for more details.

Description.1: frame size for the analysis of the input signal
Description.2: frame size for the analysis of the Onset Strength Signal
Description.3: hop size for the analysis of the input signal
Description.4: hop size for the analysis of the Onset Strength Signal
Description.5: maximum BPM to detect
Description.6: minimum BPM to detect
Description.7: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]

PercivalEnhanceHarmonics.name: PercivalEnhanceHarmonics
PercivalEnhanceHarmonics.desc:
This algorithm implements the 'Enhance Harmonics' step as described in [1].Given an input autocorrelation signal, two time-stretched versions of it (by factors of 2 and 4) are added to the original.In this way, peaks with an harmonic relation are boosted.
			For more details check the referenced paper. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_PercivalEnhanceHarmonics.html for more details.

val.array: the input signal with enhanced harmonics

PercivalEvaluatePulseTrains.name: PercivalEvaluatePulseTrains
PercivalEvaluatePulseTrains.desc:
This algorithm implements the 'Evaluate Pulse Trains' step as described in [1].Given an input onset strength signal (OSS) and a number of candidate tempo lag positions, the OSS is correlated with ideal expected pulse trains (for each candidate tempo lag) shifted in time by different amounts. The candidate tempo lag which generates the pulse train that better correlates with the OSS is returned as the preferred tempo candidate.
			For more details check the referenced paper. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_PercivalEvaluatePulseTrains.html for more details.

Description.0: onset strength signal (or other novelty curve)
Description.1: peak positions of BPM candidates

PitchContourSegmentation.name: PitchContourSegmentation
PitchContourSegmentation.desc: This algorithm converts a pitch sequence estimated from an audio signal into a set of discrete note events. Each note is defined by its onset time, duration and MIDI pitch value, quantized to the equal tempered scale. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_PitchContourSegmentation.html for more details.

Description.1: input audio signal
Description.2: hop size of the extracted pitch
Description.3: minimum note duration [s]
Description.4: pitch threshold for note segmentation [cents]
Description.5: zscore threshold for note segmentation
Description.6: sample rate of the audio signal
Description.7: tuning reference frequency [Hz]

PitchContours.name: PitchContours
PitchContours.desc: This algorithm tracks a set of predominant pitch contours of an audio signal. This algorithm is intended to receive its "frequencies" and "magnitudes" inputs from the PitchSalienceFunctionPeaks algorithm outputs aggregated over all frames in the sequence. The output is a vector of estimated melody pitch values. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_PitchContours.html for more details.

Description.0: frame-wise array of cent bins corresponding to pitch salience function peaks
Description.1: frame-wise array of values of salience function peaks
Description.2: salience function bin resolution [cents]
Description.3: the hop size with which the pitch salience function was computed
Description.4: the minimum allowed contour duration [ms]
Description.5: allowed deviation below the peak salience mean over all frames (fraction of the standard deviation)
Description.6: per-frame salience threshold factor (fraction of the highest peak salience in a frame)
Description.7: pitch continuity cue (maximum allowed pitch change durig 1 ms time period) [cents]
Description.8: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]
Description.9: time continuity cue (the maximum allowed gap duration for a pitch contour) [ms]

val.contoursBins: array of frame-wise vectors of cent bin values representing each contour
val.contoursSaliences: array of frame-wise vectors of pitch saliences representing each contour
val.contoursStartTimes: array of start times of each contour [s]
val.duration: time duration of the input signal [s]

PitchContoursMelody.name: PitchContoursMelody
PitchContoursMelody.desc:
This algorithm converts a set of pitch contours into a sequence of predominant f0 values in Hz by taking the value of the most predominant contour in each frame.
			This algorithm is intended to receive its "contoursBins", "contoursSaliences", and "contoursStartTimes" inputs from the PitchContours algorithm. The "duration" input corresponds to the time duration of the input signal. The output is a vector of estimated pitch values and a vector of confidence values. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_PitchContoursMelody.html for more details.

Description.0: array of frame-wise vectors of cent bin values representing each contour
Description.1: array of frame-wise vectors of pitch saliences representing each contour
Description.2: array of the start times of each contour [s]
Description.3: time duration of the input signal [s]
Description.4: salience function bin resolution [cents]
Description.5: number of interations for the octave errors / pitch outlier filtering process
Description.6: Estimate pitch for non-voiced segments by using non-salient contours when no salient ones are present in a frame
Description.7: the hop size with which the pitch salience function was computed
Description.8: the minimum allowed frequency for salience function peaks (ignore contours with peaks above) [Hz]
Description.9: the minimum allowed frequency for salience function peaks (ignore contours with peaks below) [Hz]
Description.10: the reference frequency for Hertz to cent convertion [Hz], corresponding to the 0th cent bin
Description.11: the sampling rate of the audio signal (Hz)
Description.13: allowed deviation below the average contour mean salience of all contours (fraction of the standard deviation)

val.pitch: vector of estimated pitch values (i.e., melody) [Hz]
val.pitchConfidence: confidence with which the pitch was detected

PitchContoursMonoMelody.name: PitchContoursMonoMelody
PitchContoursMonoMelody.desc:
This algorithm converts a set of pitch contours into a sequence of f0 values in Hz by taking the value of the most salient contour in each frame.
			In contrast to pitchContoursMelody, it assumes a single source.
			This algorithm is intended to receive its "contoursBins", "contoursSaliences", and "contoursStartTimes" inputs from the PitchContours algorithm. The "duration" input corresponds to the time duration of the input signal. The output is a vector of estimated pitch values and a vector of confidence values. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_PitchContoursMonoMelody.html for more details.

Description.0: array of frame-wise vectors of cent bin values representing each contour
Description.1: array of frame-wise vectors of pitch saliences representing each contour
Description.2: array of the start times of each contour [s]
Description.3: time duration of the input signal [s]
Description.4: salience function bin resolution [cents]
Description.5: number of interations for the octave errors / pitch outlier filtering process
Description.6: Estimate pitch for non-voiced segments by using non-salient contours when no salient ones are present in a frame
Description.7: the hop size with which the pitch salience function was computed
Description.8: the minimum allowed frequency for salience function peaks (ignore contours with peaks above) [Hz]
Description.9: the minimum allowed frequency for salience function peaks (ignore contours with peaks below) [Hz]
Description.10: the reference frequency for Hertz to cent convertion [Hz], corresponding to the 0th cent bin
Description.11: the sampling rate of the audio signal (Hz)

val.pitch: vector of estimated pitch values (i.e., melody) [Hz]
val.pitchConfidence: confidence with which the pitch was detected

PitchContoursMultiMelody.name: PitchContoursMultiMelody
PitchContoursMultiMelody.desc:
This algorithm post-processes a set of pitch contours into a sequence of mutliple f0 values in Hz.
			This algorithm is intended to receive its "contoursBins", "contoursSaliences", and "contoursStartTimes" inputs from the PitchContours algorithm. The "duration" input corresponds to the time duration of the input signal. The output is a vector of estimated pitch values Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_PitchContoursMultiMelody.html for more details.

Description.0: array of frame-wise vectors of cent bin values representing each contour
Description.1: array of frame-wise vectors of pitch saliences representing each contour
Description.2: array of the start times of each contour [s]
Description.3: time duration of the input signal [s]
Description.4: salience function bin resolution [cents]
Description.5: number of interations for the octave errors / pitch outlier filtering process
Description.6: Estimate pitch for non-voiced segments by using non-salient contours when no salient ones are present in a frame
Description.7: the hop size with which the pitch salience function was computed
Description.8: the minimum allowed frequency for salience function peaks (ignore contours with peaks above) [Hz]
Description.9: the minimum allowed frequency for salience function peaks (ignore contours with peaks below) [Hz]
Description.10: the reference frequency for Hertz to cent convertion [Hz], corresponding to the 0th cent bin
Description.11: the sampling rate of the audio signal (Hz)

val.pitch: vector of estimated pitch values (i.e., melody) [Hz]

PitchFilter.name: PitchFilter
PitchFilter.desc: This algorithm corrects the fundamental frequency estimations for a sequence of frames given pitch values together with their confidence values. In particular, it removes non-confident parts and spurious jumps in pitch and applies octave corrections. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_PitchFilter.html for more details.

Description.0: vector of pitch values for the input frames [Hz]
Description.1: vector of pitch confidence values for the input frames
Description.2: ratio between the average confidence of the most confident chunk and the minimum allowed average confidence of a chunk
Description.3: minumum number of frames in non-zero pitch chunks
Description.4: treat negative pitch confidence values as positive (use with melodia guessUnvoiced=True)

PitchMelodia.name: PitchMelodia
PitchMelodia.desc: This algorithm estimates the fundamental frequency corresponding to the melody of a monophonic music signal based on the MELODIA algorithm. While the algorithm is originally designed to extract the predominant melody from polyphonic music [1], this implementation is adapted for monophonic signals. The approach is based on the creation and characterization of pitch contours, time continuous sequences of pitch candidates grouped using auditory streaming cues. To this end, PitchSalienceFunction, PitchSalienceFunctionPeaks, PitchContours, and PitchContoursMonoMelody algorithms are employed. It is strongly advised to use the default parameter values which are optimized according to [1] (where further details are provided) except for minFrequency and maxFrequency, which will depend on your application. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_PitchMelodia.html for more details.

Description.1: salience function bin resolution [cents]
Description.2: number of iterations for the octave errors / pitch outlier filtering process
Description.3: the frame size for computing pitch saliecnce
Description.4: estimate pitch for non-voiced segments by using non-salient contours when no salient ones are present in a frame
Description.5: harmonic weighting parameter (weight decay ratio between two consequent harmonics, =1 for no decay)
Description.6: the hop size with which the pitch salience function was computed
Description.7: magnitude compression parameter for the salience function (=0 for maximum compression, =1 for no compression)
Description.8: spectral peak magnitude threshold (maximum allowed difference from the highest peak in dBs)
Description.9: the minimum allowed frequency for salience function peaks (ignore contours with peaks above) [Hz]
Description.10: the minimum allowed contour duration [ms]
Description.11: the minimum allowed frequency for salience function peaks (ignore contours with peaks below) [Hz]
Description.13: allowed deviation below the peak salience mean over all frames (fraction of the standard deviation)
Description.14: per-frame salience threshold factor (fraction of the highest peak salience in a frame)
Description.15: pitch continuity cue (maximum allowed pitch change during 1 ms time period) [cents]
Description.16: the reference frequency for Hertz to cent convertion [Hz], corresponding to the 0th cent bin
Description.17: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]
Description.18: time continuity cue (the maximum allowed gap duration for a pitch contour) [ms]

val.pitchConfidence: confidence with which the pitch was detected

PitchSalience.name: PitchSalience
PitchSalience.desc: This algorithm computes the pitch salience of a spectrum. The pitch salience is given by the ratio of the highest auto correlation value of the spectrum to the non-shifted auto correlation value. Pitch salience was designed as quick measure of tone sensation. Unpitched sounds (non-musical sound effects) and pure tones have an average pitch salience value close to 0 whereas sounds containing several harmonics in the spectrum tend to have a higher value. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_PitchSalience.html for more details.

Description.1: until which frequency we are looking for the minimum (must be smaller than half sampleRate) [Hz]
Description.2: from which frequency we are looking for the maximum (must not be larger than highBoundary) [Hz]
Description.3: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]

PitchSalienceFunction.name: PitchSalienceFunction
PitchSalienceFunction.desc: This algorithm computes the pitch salience function of a signal frame given its spectral peaks. The salience function covers a pitch range of nearly five octaves (i.e., 6000 cents), starting from the "referenceFrequency", and is quantized into cent bins according to the specified "binResolution". The salience of a given frequency is computed as the sum of the weighted energies found at integer multiples (harmonics) of that frequency.  Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_PitchSalienceFunction.html for more details.

Description.0: the frequencies of the spectral peaks [Hz]
Description.1: the magnitudes of the spectral peaks
Description.2: salience function bin resolution [cents]
Description.3: harmonic weighting parameter (weight decay ratio between two consequent harmonics, =1 for no decay)
Description.4: magnitude compression parameter (=0 for maximum compression, =1 for no compression)
Description.5: peak magnitude threshold (maximum allowed difference from the highest peak in dBs)
Description.6: number of considered harmonics
Description.7: the reference frequency for Hertz to cent convertion [Hz], corresponding to the 0th cent bin

val.salienceFunction: array of the quantized pitch salience values

PitchSalienceFunctionPeaks.name: PitchSalienceFunctionPeaks
PitchSalienceFunctionPeaks.desc: This algorithm computes the peaks of a given pitch salience function. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_PitchSalienceFunctionPeaks.html for more details.

Description.0: the array of salience function values corresponding to cent frequency bins
Description.1: salience function bin resolution [cents]
Description.2: the maximum frequency to evaluate (ignore peaks above) [Hz]
Description.3: the minimum frequency to evaluate (ignore peaks below) [Hz]
Description.4: the reference frequency for Hertz to cent convertion [Hz], corresponding to the 0th cent bin

val.salienceBins: the cent bins corresponding to salience function peaks
val.salienceValues: the values of salience function peaks

PitchYin.name: PitchYin
PitchYin.desc: This algorithm estimates the fundamental frequency given the frame of a monophonic music signal. It is an implementation of the Yin algorithm [1] for computations in the time domain. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_PitchYin.html for more details.

Description.1: number of samples in the input frame (this is an optional parameter to optimize memory allocation)
Description.2: enable interpolation
Description.3: the maximum allowed frequency [Hz]
Description.4: the minimum allowed frequency [Hz]
Description.5: sampling rate of the input audio [Hz]
Description.6: tolerance for peak detection

val.pitchConfidence: confidence with which the pitch was detected [0,1]

PitchYinFFT.name: PitchYinFFT
PitchYinFFT.desc: This algorithm estimates the fundamental frequency given the spectrum of a monophonic music signal. It is an implementation of YinFFT algorithm [1], which is an optimized version of Yin algorithm for computation in the frequency domain. It is recommended to window the input spectrum with a Hann window. The raw spectrum can be computed with the Spectrum algorithm. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_PitchYinFFT.html for more details.

Description.0: the input spectrum (preferably created with a hann window)
Description.1: number of samples in the input spectrum
Description.2: boolean flag to enable interpolation
Description.3: the maximum allowed frequency [Hz]
Description.4: the minimum allowed frequency [Hz]
Description.5: sampling rate of the input spectrum [Hz]
Description.6: tolerance for peak detection

val.pitchConfidence: confidence with which the pitch was detected [0,1]

PitchYinProbabilistic.name: PitchYinProbabilistic
PitchYinProbabilistic.desc: This algorithm computes the pitch track of a mono audio signal using probabilistic Yin algorithm. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_PitchYinProbabilistic.html for more details.

Description.1: the frame size of FFT
Description.2: the hop size with which the pitch is computed
Description.3: the low RMS amplitude threshold
Description.4: whether output unvoiced frame, zero: output non-voiced pitch as 0.; abs: output non-voiced pitch as absolute values; negative: output non-voiced pitch as negative values
Description.5: use non-standard precise YIN timing (slow).
Description.6: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]

PitchYinProbabilities.name: PitchYinProbabilities
PitchYinProbabilities.desc: This algorithm estimates the fundamental frequencies, their probabilities given the frame of a monophonic music signal. It is a part of the implementation of the probabilistic Yin algorithm [1]. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_PitchYinProbabilities.html for more details.

Description.1: number of samples in the input frame
Description.2: the low RMS amplitude threshold
Description.3: use non-standard precise YIN timing (slow).
Description.4: sampling rate of the input audio [Hz]

val.pitch: the output pitch candidate frequencies in cents

PitchYinProbabilitiesHMM.name: PitchYinProbabilitiesHMM
PitchYinProbabilitiesHMM.desc: This algorithm estimates the smoothed fundamental frequency given the pitch candidates and probabilities using hidden Markov models. It is a part of the implementation of the probabilistic Yin algorithm [1]. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_PitchYinProbabilitiesHMM.html for more details.

Description.1: the pitch probabilities
Description.2: minimum detected frequency
Description.3: number of bins per semitone
Description.4: the self transition probabilities
Description.5: the yin trust parameter

PowerMean.name: PowerMean
PowerMean.desc: This algorithm computes the power mean of an array. It accepts one parameter, p, which is the power (or order or degree) of the Power Mean. Note that if p=-1, the Power Mean is equal to the Harmonic Mean, if p=0, the Power Mean is equal to the Geometric Mean, if p=1, the Power Mean is equal to the Arithmetic Mean, if p=2, the Power Mean is equal to the Root Mean Square. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_PowerMean.html for more details.

Description.0: the input array (must contain only positive real numbers)
Description.1: the power to which to elevate each element before taking the mean

val.powerMean: the power mean of the input array

PowerSpectrum.name: PowerSpectrum
PowerSpectrum.desc: This algorithm computes the power spectrum of an array of Reals. The resulting power spectrum has a size which is half the size of the input array plus one. Bins contain squared magnitude values. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_PowerSpectrum.html for more details.

Description.1: the expected size of the input frame (this is purely optional and only targeted at optimizing the creation time of the FFT object)

val.powerSpectrum: power spectrum of the input signal

PredominantPitchMelodia.name: PredominantPitchMelodia
PredominantPitchMelodia.desc: This algorithm estimates the fundamental frequency of the predominant melody from polyphonic music signals using the MELODIA algorithm. It is specifically suited for music with a predominent melodic element, for example the singing voice melody in an accompanied singing recording. The approach [1] is based on the creation and characterization of pitch contours, time continuous sequences of pitch candidates grouped using auditory streaming cues. It furthermore determines for each frame, if the predominant melody is present or not. To this end, PitchSalienceFunction, PitchSalienceFunctionPeaks, PitchContours, and PitchContoursMelody algorithms are employed. It is strongly advised to use the default parameter values which are optimized according to [1] (where further details are provided) except for minFrequency, maxFrequency, and voicingTolerance, which will depend on your application. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_PredominantPitchMelodia.html for more details.

Description.1: salience function bin resolution [cents]
Description.2: number of iterations for the octave errors / pitch outlier filtering process
Description.3: the frame size for computing pitch salience
Description.4: estimate pitch for non-voiced segments by using non-salient contours when no salient ones are present in a frame
Description.5: harmonic weighting parameter (weight decay ratio between two consequent harmonics, =1 for no decay)
Description.6: the hop size with which the pitch salience function was computed
Description.7: magnitude compression parameter for the salience function (=0 for maximum compression, =1 for no compression)
Description.8: spectral peak magnitude threshold (maximum allowed difference from the highest peak in dBs)
Description.9: the minimum allowed frequency for salience function peaks (ignore contours with peaks above) [Hz]
Description.10: the minimum allowed contour duration [ms]
Description.11: the minimum allowed frequency for salience function peaks (ignore contours with peaks below) [Hz]
Description.13: allowed deviation below the peak salience mean over all frames (fraction of the standard deviation)
Description.14: per-frame salience threshold factor (fraction of the highest peak salience in a frame)
Description.15: pitch continuity cue (maximum allowed pitch change during 1 ms time period) [cents]
Description.16: the reference frequency for Hertz to cent conversion [Hz], corresponding to the 0th cent bin
Description.17: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]
Description.18: time continuity cue (the maximum allowed gap duration for a pitch contour) [ms]
Description.20: allowed deviation below the average contour mean salience of all contours (fraction of the standard deviation)

val.pitchConfidence: confidence with which the pitch was detected

RMS.name: RMS
RMS.desc:
This algorithm computes the root mean square (quadratic mean) of an array.
			RMS is not defined for empty arrays. In such case, an exception will be thrown
			.
			References:
			[1] Root mean square - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia,
			http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Root_mean_square Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_RMS.html for more details.

val.rms: the root mean square of the input array

RawMoments.name: RawMoments
RawMoments.desc: This algorithm computes the first 5 raw moments of an array. The output array is of size 6 because the zero-ith moment is used for padding so that the first moment corresponds to index 1. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_RawMoments.html for more details.

Description.1: the range of the input array, used for normalizing the results

val.rawMoments: the (raw) moments of the input array

ReplayGain.name: ReplayGain
ReplayGain.desc: This algorithm computes the Replay Gain loudness value of an audio signal. The algorithm is described in detail in [1]. The value returned is the 'standard' ReplayGain value, not the value with 6dB preamplification as computed by lame, mp3gain, vorbisgain, and all widely used ReplayGain programs. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_ReplayGain.html for more details.

Description.0: the input audio signal (must be longer than 0.05ms)
Description.1: the sampling rate of the input audio signal [Hz]

val.replayGain: the distance to the suitable average replay level (~-31dbB) defined by SMPTE [dB]

Resample.name: Resample
Resample.desc: This algorithm resamples the input signal to the desired sampling rate. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_Resample.html for more details.

Description.1: the sampling rate of the input signal [Hz]
Description.2: the sampling rate of the output signal [Hz]
Description.3: the quality of the conversion, 0 for best quality

ResampleFFT.name: ResampleFFT
ResampleFFT.desc: This algorithm resamples a sequence using FFT / IFFT. The input and output sizes must be an even number. (It is meant to be eqivalent to the resample function in Numpy). Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_ResampleFFT.html for more details.

Description.1: the size of the input sequence. It needss to be even-sized.
Description.2: the size of the output sequence. It needss to be even-sized.

RhythmDescriptors.name: RhythmDescriptors
RhythmDescriptors.desc: This algorithm computes rhythm features (bpm, beat positions, beat histogram peaks) for an audio signal. It combines RhythmExtractor2013 for beat tracking and BPM estimation with BpmHistogramDescriptors algorithms. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_RhythmDescriptors.html for more details.

RhythmExtractor.name: RhythmExtractor
RhythmExtractor.desc:
This algorithm estimates the tempo in bpm and beat positions given an audio signal. The algorithm combines several periodicity functions and estimates beats using TempoTap and TempoTapTicks. It combines:
			- onset detection functions based on high-frequency content (see OnsetDetection)
			- complex-domain spectral difference function (see OnsetDetection)
			- periodicity function based on energy bands (see FrequencyBands, TempoScaleBands) Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_RhythmExtractor.html for more details.

Description.1: the number of feature frames separating two evaluations
Description.2: the number audio samples used to compute a feature
Description.3: the number of audio samples per features
Description.4: the minimum interval between last beat and end of file [s]
Description.5: the fastest tempo to detect [bpm]
Description.6: the slowest tempo to detect [bpm]
Description.7: the number of feature frames to buffer on
Description.8: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]
Description.9: the optional list of initial beat locations, to favor the detection of pre-determined tempo period and beats alignment [s]
Description.10: the minimum interval between two consecutive beats [s]
Description.11: whether or not to use band energy as periodicity function
Description.12: whether or not to use onsets as periodicity function

RhythmExtractor2013.name: RhythmExtractor2013
RhythmExtractor2013.desc:
This algorithm extracts the beat positions and estimates their confidence as well as tempo in bpm for an audio signal. The beat locations can be computed using:
			- 'multifeature', the BeatTrackerMultiFeature algorithm
			- 'degara', the BeatTrackerDegara algorithm (note that there is no confidence estimation for this method, the output confidence value is always 0) Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_RhythmExtractor2013.html for more details.

Description.1: the fastest tempo to detect [bpm]
Description.2: the method used for beat tracking
Description.3: the slowest tempo to detect [bpm]

val.confidence: confidence with which the ticks are detected (ignore this value if using 'degara' method)
val.estimates: the list of bpm estimates characterizing the bpm distribution for the signal [bpm]

RhythmTransform.name: RhythmTransform
RhythmTransform.desc: This algorithm implements the rhythm transform. It computes a tempogram, a representation of rhythmic periodicities in the input signal in the rhythm domain, by using FFT similarly to computation of spectrum in the frequency domain [1]. Additional features, including rhythmic centroid and a rhythmic counterpart of MFCCs, can be derived from this rhythmic representation. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_RhythmTransform.html for more details.

Description.0: the energies in the mel bands
Description.1: the frame size to compute the rhythm trasform
Description.2: the hop size to compute the rhythm transform

val.rhythm: consecutive frames in the rhythm domain

RollOff.name: RollOff
RollOff.desc: This algorithm computes the roll-off frequency of a spectrum. The roll-off frequency is defined as the frequency under which some percentage (cutoff) of the total energy of the spectrum is contained. The roll-off frequency can be used to distinguish between harmonic (below roll-off) and noisy sounds (above roll-off). Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_RollOff.html for more details.

Description.0: the input audio spectrum (must have more than one elements)
Description.1: the ratio of total energy to attain before yielding the roll-off frequency
Description.2: the sampling rate of the audio signal (used to normalize rollOff) [Hz]

SNR.name: SNR
SNR.desc:
This algorithm computes the SNR of the input audio in a frame-wise manner. The algorithm assumes that:
			1. The noise is gaussian.
			2. There is a region of noise (without signal) at the beginning of the stream in order to estimate the PSD of the noise.[1]
			Once the noise PSD is estimated, the algorithm relies on the Ephraim-Malah [2] recursion to estimate the SNR for each frequency bin.
			The algorithm also returns an overall (a single value for the whole spectrum) SNR estimation and an averaged overall SNR estimation using Exponential Moving Average filtering.
			This algorithm throws a Warning if less than 15 frames are used to estimte the noise PSD. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_SNR.html for more details.

Description.1: Alpha coefficient for the EMA SNR estimation [2]
Description.2: Alpha coefficient for the MMSE estimation [1].
Description.3: Alpha coefficient for the EMA noise estimation [2]
Description.4: the size of the input frame
Description.5: Threshold to detect frames without signal
Description.6: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]
Description.7: flag to apply the -10 * log10(BW) broadband noise correction factor

val.instantSNR: SNR value for the the current frame
val.averagedSNR: averaged SNR through an Exponential Moving Average filter
val.spectralSNR: instant SNR for each frequency bin

SaturationDetector.name: SaturationDetector
SaturationDetector.desc:
this algorithm outputs the staring/ending locations of the saturated regions in seconds. Saturated regions are found by means of a tripe criterion:
			1. samples in a saturated region should have more energy than a given threshold.
			2. the difference between the samples in a saturated region should be smaller than a given threshold.
			3. the duration of the saturated region should be longer than a given threshold. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_SaturationDetector.html for more details.

Description.1: minimum difference between contiguous samples of the salturated regions
Description.2: mininimum energy of the samples in the saturated regions [dB]
Description.3: expected input frame size
Description.4: hop size used for the analysis
Description.5: minimum duration of the saturated regions [ms]
Description.6: sample rate used for the analysis

val.starts: starting times of the detected saturated regions [s]
val.ends: ending times of the detected saturated regions [s]

Scale.name: Scale
Scale.desc: This algorithm scales the audio by the specified factor using clipping if required. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_Scale.html for more details.

Description.1: boolean flag whether to apply clipping or not
Description.2: the multiplication factor by which the audio will be scaled
Description.3: the maximum value above which to apply clipping

SineSubtraction.name: SineSubtraction
SineSubtraction.desc: This algorithm subtracts the sinusoids computed with the sine model analysis from an input audio signal. It ouputs an audio signal. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_SineSubtraction.html for more details.

Description.0: the input audio frame to subtract from
Description.1: the magnitudes of the sinusoidal peaks
Description.2: the frequencies of the sinusoidal peaks [Hz]
Description.3: the phases of the sinusoidal peaks
Description.4: the size of the FFT internal process (full spectrum size) and output frame. Minimum twice the hopsize.
Description.5: the hop size between frames
Description.6: the audio sampling rate [Hz]

SingleBeatLoudness.name: SingleBeatLoudness
SingleBeatLoudness.desc: This algorithm computes the spectrum energy of a single beat across the whole frequency range and on each specified frequency band given an audio segment. It detects the onset of the beat within the input segment, computes spectrum on a window starting on this onset, and estimates energy (see Energy and EnergyBandRatio algorithms). The frequency bands used by default are: 0-200 Hz, 200-400 Hz, 400-800 Hz, 800-1600 Hz, 1600-3200 Hz, 3200-22000Hz, following E. Scheirer [1]. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_SingleBeatLoudness.html for more details.

Description.1: window size for the beat's energy computation (the window starts at the onset) [s]
Description.2: window size for the beat's onset detection [s]
Description.3: frequency bands
Description.4: criteria for finding the start of the beat
Description.5: the audio sampling rate [Hz]

val.loudness: the beat's energy across the whole spectrum
val.loudnessBandRatio: the beat's energy ratio for each band

Slicer.name: Slicer
Slicer.desc: This algorithm splits an audio signal into segments given their start and end times. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_Slicer.html for more details.

Description.1: the list of end times for the slices you want to extract
Description.2: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]
Description.3: the list of start times for the slices you want to extract
Description.4: the units of time of the start and end times

val.frame: the frames of the sliced input signal

SpectralCentroidTime.name: SpectralCentroidTime
SpectralCentroidTime.desc:
This algorithm computes the spectral centroid of a signal in time domain. A first difference filter is applied to the input signal. Then the centroid is computed by dividing the norm of the resulting signal by the norm of the input signal. The centroid is given in hertz.
			References:
			[1] Udo Zlzer (2002). DAFX Digital Audio Effects pag.364-365
			Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_SpectralCentroidTime.html for more details.

Description.1: sampling rate of the input spectrum [Hz]

val.centroid: the spectral centroid of the signal

SpectralComplexity.name: SpectralComplexity
SpectralComplexity.desc: This algorithm computes the spectral complexity of a spectrum. The spectral complexity is based on the number of peaks in the input spectrum. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_SpectralComplexity.html for more details.

Description.1: the minimum spectral-peak magnitude that contributes to spectral complexity
Description.2: the audio sampling rate [Hz]

val.spectralComplexity: the spectral complexity of the input spectrum

SpectralContrast.name: SpectralContrast
SpectralContrast.desc: This algorithm computes the Spectral Contrast feature of a spectrum. It is based on the Octave Based Spectral Contrast feature as described in [1]. The version implemented here is a modified version to improve discriminative power and robustness. The modifications are described in [2]. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_SpectralContrast.html for more details.

Description.1: the size of the fft frames
Description.2: the upper bound of the highest band
Description.3: the lower bound of the lowest band
Description.4: the ratio of the bins in the sub band used to calculate the peak and valley
Description.5: the number of bands in the filter
Description.6: the sampling rate of the audio signal
Description.7: the ratio of the bins to distribute equally

SpectralPeaks.name: SpectralPeaks
SpectralPeaks.desc: This algorithm extracts peaks from a spectrum. It is important to note that the peak algorithm is independent of an input that is linear or in dB, so one has to adapt the threshold to fit with the type of data fed to it. The algorithm relies on PeakDetection algorithm which is run with parabolic interpolation [1]. The exactness of the peak-searching depends heavily on the windowing type. It gives best results with dB input, a blackman-harris 92dB window and interpolation set to true. According to [1], spectral peak frequencies tend to be about twice as accurate when dB magnitude is used rather than just linear magnitude. For further information about the peak detection, see the description of the PeakDetection algorithm. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_SpectralPeaks.html for more details.

Description.1: peaks below this given threshold are not outputted
Description.2: the maximum frequency of the range to evaluate [Hz]
Description.3: the maximum number of returned peaks
Description.4: the minimum frequency of the range to evaluate [Hz]
Description.5: the ordering type of the outputted peaks (ascending by frequency or descending by magnitude)
Description.6: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]

val.frequencies: the frequencies of the spectral peaks [Hz]
val.magnitudes: the magnitudes of the spectral peaks

SpectralWhitening.name: SpectralWhitening
SpectralWhitening.desc: Performs spectral whitening of spectral peaks of a spectrum. The algorithm works in dB scale, but the conversion is done by the algorithm so input should be in linear scale. The concept of 'whitening' refers to 'white noise' or a non-zero flat spectrum. It first computes a spectral envelope similar to the 'true envelope' in [1], and then modifies the amplitude of each peak relative to the envelope. For example, the predominant peaks will have a value close to 0dB because they are very close to the envelope. On the other hand, minor peaks between significant peaks will have lower amplitudes such as -30dB. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_SpectralWhitening.html for more details.

Description.1: the spectral peaks' linear frequencies
Description.2: the spectral peaks' linear magnitudes
Description.3: max frequency to apply whitening to [Hz]
Description.4: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]

val.magnitudes: the whitened spectral peaks' linear magnitudes

Spectrum.name: Spectrum
Spectrum.desc: This algorithm computes the magnitude spectrum of an array of Reals. The resulting magnitude spectrum has a size which is half the size of the input array plus one. Bins contain raw (linear) magnitude values. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_Spectrum.html for more details.

Description.1: the expected size of the input audio signal (this is an optional parameter to optimize memory allocation)

val.spectrum: magnitude spectrum of the input audio signal

SpectrumCQ.name: SpectrumCQ
SpectrumCQ.desc:
This algorithm computes the magnitude of the Constant-Q spectrum. See ConstantQ algorithm for more details.
			Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_SpectrumCQ.html for more details.

Description.1: number of bins per octave
Description.2: minimum frequency [Hz]
Description.3: minimum size allowed for frequency kernels
Description.4: number of frequency bins, starting at minFrequency
Description.5: FFT sampling rate [Hz]
Description.6: filters scale. Larger values use longer windows
Description.7: bins whose magnitude is below this quantile are discarded
Description.8: the window type, which can be 'hamming', 'hann', 'triangular', 'square' or 'blackmanharrisXX'
Description.9: a boolean value that enables zero-phase windowing. Input audio frames should be windowed with the same phase mode

SpectrumToCent.name: SpectrumToCent
SpectrumToCent.desc: This algorithm computes energy in triangular frequency bands of a spectrum equally spaced on the cent scale. Each band is computed to have a constant wideness in the cent scale. For each band the power-spectrum (mag-squared) is summed. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_SpectrumToCent.html for more details.

Description.0: the input spectrum (must be greater than size one)
Description.1: number of bins to compute. Default is 720 (6 octaves with the default 'centBinResolution')
Description.2: Width of each band in cents. Default is 10 cents
Description.3: the size of the spectrum
Description.4: compute log-energies (log10 (1 + energy))
Description.5: central frequency of the first band of the bank [Hz]
Description.6: use unit area or vertex equal to 1 triangles.
Description.7: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]
Description.8: use magnitude or power spectrum

val.frequencies: the central frequency of each band

Spline.name: Spline
Spline.desc:
Evaluates a piecewise spline of type b, beta or quadratic.
			The input value, i.e. the point at which the spline is to be evaluated typically should be between xPoins[0] and xPoinst[size-1]. If the value lies outside this range, extrapolation is used.
			Regarding spline types:
			- B: evaluates a cubic B spline approximant.
			- Beta: evaluates a cubic beta spline approximant. For beta splines parameters 'beta1' and 'beta2' can be supplied. For no bias set beta1 to 1 and for no tension set beta2 to 0. Note that if beta1=1 and beta2=0, the cubic beta becomes a cubic B spline. On the other hand if beta1=1 and beta2 is large the beta spline turns into a linear spline.
			- Quadratic: evaluates a piecewise quadratic spline at a point. Note that size of input must be odd. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_Spline.html for more details.

Description.1: the skew or bias parameter (only available for type beta)
Description.2: the tension parameter
Description.3: the type of spline to be computed
Description.4: the x-coordinates where data is specified (the points must be arranged in ascending order and cannot contain duplicates)
Description.5: the y-coordinates to be interpolated (i.e. the known data)

val.y: the value of the spline at x

SprModelAnal.name: SprModelAnal
SprModelAnal.desc: This algorithm computes the sinusoidal plus residual model analysis.  Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_SprModelAnal.html for more details.

Description.1: the size of the internal FFT size (full spectrum size)
Description.2: minimum frequency deviation at 0Hz
Description.3: slope increase of minimum frequency deviation
Description.4: the hop size between frames
Description.5: peaks below this given threshold are not outputted
Description.6: the maximum frequency of the range to evaluate [Hz]
Description.7: the maximum number of returned peaks
Description.8: maximum number of sines per frame
Description.9: the minimum frequency of the range to evaluate [Hz]
Description.10: the ordering type of the outputted peaks (ascending by frequency or descending by magnitude)
Description.11: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]

val.frequencies: the frequencies of the sinusoidal peaks [Hz]
val.magnitudes: the magnitudes of the sinusoidal peaks
val.phases: the phases of the sinusoidal peaks

SprModelSynth.name: SprModelSynth
SprModelSynth.desc: This algorithm computes the sinusoidal plus residual model synthesis from SPS model analysis. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_SprModelSynth.html for more details.

Description.0: the magnitudes of the sinusoidal peaks
Description.1: the frequencies of the sinusoidal peaks [Hz]
Description.2: the phases of the sinusoidal peaks
Description.3: the residual frame
Description.4: the size of the output FFT frame (full spectrum size)
Description.5: the hop size between frames
Description.6: the audio sampling rate [Hz]

val.frame: the output audio frame of the Sinusoidal Plus Stochastic model
val.sineframe: the output audio frame for sinusoidal component
val.resframe: the output audio frame for stochastic component

SpsModelAnal.name: SpsModelAnal
SpsModelAnal.desc: This algorithm computes the stochastic model analysis.  Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_SpsModelAnal.html for more details.

Description.1: the size of the internal FFT size (full spectrum size)
Description.2: minimum frequency deviation at 0Hz
Description.3: slope increase of minimum frequency deviation
Description.4: the hop size between frames
Description.5: peaks below this given threshold are not outputted
Description.6: the maximum frequency of the range to evaluate [Hz]
Description.7: the maximum number of returned peaks
Description.8: maximum number of sines per frame
Description.9: the minimum frequency of the range to evaluate [Hz]
Description.10: the ordering type of the outputted peaks (ascending by frequency or descending by magnitude)
Description.11: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]
Description.12: decimation factor used for the stochastic approximation

val.frequencies: the frequencies of the sinusoidal peaks [Hz]
val.magnitudes: the magnitudes of the sinusoidal peaks
val.phases: the phases of the sinusoidal peaks

SpsModelSynth.name: SpsModelSynth
SpsModelSynth.desc: This algorithm computes the sinusoidal plus stochastic model synthesis from SPS model analysis. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_SpsModelSynth.html for more details.

Description.0: the magnitudes of the sinusoidal peaks
Description.1: the frequencies of the sinusoidal peaks [Hz]
Description.2: the phases of the sinusoidal peaks
Description.3: the stochastic envelope
Description.4: the size of the output FFT frame (full spectrum size)
Description.5: the hop size between frames
Description.6: the audio sampling rate [Hz]
Description.7: decimation factor used for the stochastic approximation

val.frame: the output audio frame of the Sinusoidal Plus Stochastic model
val.sineframe: the output audio frame for sinusoidal component
val.stocframe: the output audio frame for stochastic component

StartStopCut.name: StartStopCut
StartStopCut.desc: This algorithm outputs if there is a cut at the beginning or at the end of the audio by locating the first and last non-silent frames and comparing their positions to the actual beginning and end of the audio. The input audio is considered to be cut at the beginning (or the end) and the corresponding flag is activated if the first (last) non-silent frame occurs before (after) the configurable time threshold. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_StartStopCut.html for more details.

Description.1: the frame size for the internal power analysis
Description.2: the hop size for the internal power analysis
Description.3: if the first non-silent frame occurs before maximumStartTime startCut is activated [ms]
Description.4: if the last non-silent frame occurs after maximumStopTime to the end stopCut is activated [ms]
Description.5: the sample rate
Description.6: the threshold below which average energy is defined as silence [dB]

val.startCut: 1 if there is a cut at the begining of the audio
val.stopCut: 1 if there is a cut at the end of the audio

StartStopSilence.name: StartStopSilence
StartStopSilence.desc: This algorithm outputs the frame at which sound begins and the frame at which sound ends. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_StartStopSilence.html for more details.

Description.1: the threshold below which average energy is defined as silence [dB]

val.startFrame: number of the first non-silent frame
val.stopFrame: number of the last non-silent frame

StochasticModelAnal.name: StochasticModelAnal
StochasticModelAnal.desc: This algorithm computes the stochastic model analysis. It gets the resampled spectral envelope of the stochastic component. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_StochasticModelAnal.html for more details.

Description.1: the size of the internal FFT size (full spectrum size)
Description.2: the hop size between frames
Description.3: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]
Description.4: decimation factor used for the stochastic approximation

StochasticModelSynth.name: StochasticModelSynth
StochasticModelSynth.desc: This algorithm computes the stochastic model synthesis. It generates the noisy spectrum from a resampled spectral envelope of the stochastic component. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_StochasticModelSynth.html for more details.

Description.1: the size of the internal FFT size (full spectrum size)
Description.2: the hop size between frames
Description.3: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]
Description.4: decimation factor used for the stochastic approximation

StrongDecay.name: StrongDecay
StrongDecay.desc: This algorithm computes the Strong Decay of an audio signal. The Strong Decay is built from the non-linear combination of the signal energy and the signal temporal centroid, the latter being the balance of the absolute value of the signal. A signal containing a temporal centroid near its start boundary and a strong energy is said to have a strong decay. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_StrongDecay.html for more details.

Description.1: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]

StrongPeak.name: StrongPeak
StrongPeak.desc: This algorithm computes the Strong Peak of a spectrum. The Strong Peak is defined as the ratio between the spectrum's maximum peak's magnitude and the "bandwidth" of the peak above a threshold (half its amplitude). This ratio reveals whether the spectrum presents a very "pronounced" maximum peak (i.e. the thinner and the higher the maximum of the spectrum is, the higher the ratio value). Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_StrongPeak.html for more details.

Description.0: the input spectrum (must be greater than one element and cannot contain negative values)

SuperFluxExtractor.name: SuperFluxExtractor
SuperFluxExtractor.desc: This algorithm detects onsets given an audio signal using SuperFlux algorithm. This implementation is based on the available reference implementation in python [2]. The algorithm computes spectrum of the input signal, summarizes it into triangular band energies, and computes a onset detection function based on spectral flux tracking spectral trajectories with a maximum filter (SuperFluxNovelty). The peaks of the function are then detected (SuperFluxPeaks). Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_SuperFluxExtractor.html for more details.

Description.1: time threshold for double onsets detections (ms)
Description.2: the frame size for computing low-level features
Description.3: the hop size for computing low-level features
Description.4: ratio threshold for peak picking with respect to novelty_signal/novelty_average rate, use 0 to disable it (for low-energy onsets)
Description.5: the audio sampling rate [Hz]
Description.6: threshold for peak peaking with respect to the difference between novelty_signal and average_signal (for onsets in ambient noise)

SuperFluxNovelty.name: SuperFluxNovelty
SuperFluxNovelty.desc: Onset detection function for Superflux algorithm. See SuperFluxExtractor for more details. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_SuperFluxNovelty.html for more details.

Description.1: filter width (number of frequency bins)
Description.2: differentiation offset (compute the difference with the N-th previous frame)

SuperFluxPeaks.name: SuperFluxPeaks
SuperFluxPeaks.desc: This algorithm detects peaks of an onset detection function computed by the SuperFluxNovelty algorithm. See SuperFluxExtractor for more details. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_SuperFluxPeaks.html for more details.

Description.1: time threshold for double onsets detections (ms)
Description.2: frameRate
Description.3: look back duration for moving average filter [ms]
Description.4: look back duration for moving maximum filter [ms]
Description.5: ratio threshold for peak picking with respect to novelty_signal/novelty_average rate, use 0 to disable it (for low-energy onsets)
Description.6: threshold for peak peaking with respect to the difference between novelty_signal and average_signal (for onsets in ambient noise)

TCToTotal.name: TCToTotal
TCToTotal.desc: This algorithm calculates the ratio of the temporal centroid to the total length of a signal envelope. This ratio shows how the sound is 'balanced'. Its value is close to 0 if most of the energy lies at the beginning of the sound (e.g. decrescendo or impulsive sounds), close to 0.5 if the sound is symetric (e.g. 'delta unvarying' sounds), and close to 1 if most of the energy lies at the end of the sound (e.g. crescendo sounds). Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_TCToTotal.html for more details.

Description.0: the envelope of the signal (its length must be greater than 1

val.TCToTotal: the temporal centroid to total length ratio

TempoScaleBands.name: TempoScaleBands
TempoScaleBands.desc: This algorithm computes features for tempo tracking to be used with the TempoTap algorithm. See standard_rhythmextractor_tempotap in examples folder. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_TempoScaleBands.html for more details.

Description.0: the audio power spectrum divided into bands
Description.1: gain for each bands
Description.2: the frame rate in samples

val.cumulativeBands: cumulative sum of the output bands before scaling

TempoTap.name: TempoTap
TempoTap.desc:
This algorithm estimates the periods and phases of a periodic signal, represented by a sequence of values of any number of detection functions, such as energy bands, onsets locations, etc. It requires to be sequentially run on a vector of such values ("featuresFrame") for each particular audio frame in order to get estimations related to that frames. The estimations are done for each detection function separately, utilizing the latest "frameHop" frames, including the present one, to compute autocorrelation. Empty estimations will be returned until enough frames are accumulated in the algorithm's buffer.
			The algorithm uses elements of the following beat-tracking methods:
			- BeatIt, elaborated by Fabien Gouyon and Simon Dixon (input features) [1]
			- Multi-comb filter with Rayleigh weighting, Mathew Davies [2] Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_TempoTap.html for more details.

Description.0: input temporal features of a frame
Description.1: number of feature frames separating two evaluations
Description.2: number of audio samples in a frame
Description.3: fastest tempo allowed to be detected [bpm]
Description.4: slowest tempo allowed to be detected [bpm]
Description.5: number of feature frames to buffer on
Description.6: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]
Description.7: optional list of initial beat locations, to favor the detection of pre-determined tempo period and beats alignment [s]

val.periods: list of tempo estimates found for each input feature, in frames
val.phases: list of initial phase candidates found for each input feature, in frames

TempoTapDegara.name: TempoTapDegara
TempoTapDegara.desc: This algorithm estimates beat positions given an onset detection function.  The detection function is partitioned into 6-second frames with a 1.5-second increment, and the autocorrelation is computed for each frame, and is weighted by a tempo preference curve [2]. Periodicity estimations are done frame-wisely, searching for the best match with the Viterbi algorith [3]. The estimated periods are then passed to the probabilistic beat tracking algorithm [1], which computes beat positions. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_TempoTapDegara.html for more details.

Description.0: the input frame-wise vector of onset detection values
Description.1: fastest tempo allowed to be detected [bpm]
Description.2: slowest tempo allowed to be detected [bpm]
Description.3: use upsampling of the onset detection function (may increase accuracy)
Description.4: the sampling rate of the onset detection function [Hz]

TempoTapMaxAgreement.name: TempoTapMaxAgreement
TempoTapMaxAgreement.desc: This algorithm outputs beat positions and confidence of their estimation based on the maximum mutual agreement between beat candidates estimated by different beat trackers (or using different features). Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_TempoTapMaxAgreement.html for more details.

Description.0: the tick candidates estimated using different beat trackers (or features) [s]

val.confidence: confidence with which the ticks were detected [0, 5.32]

TempoTapTicks.name: TempoTapTicks
TempoTapTicks.desc: This algorithm builds the list of ticks from the period and phase candidates given by the TempoTap algorithm. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_TempoTapTicks.html for more details.

Description.0: tempo period candidates for the current frame, in frames
Description.1: tempo ticks phase candidates for the current frame, in frames
Description.2: number of feature frames separating two evaluations
Description.3: number of audio samples per features
Description.4: sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]

TensorflowInputMusiCNN.name: TensorflowInputMusiCNN
TensorflowInputMusiCNN.desc: This algorithm computes mel-bands with a particular parametrization specific to MusiCNN based models. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_TensorflowInputMusiCNN.html for more details.

TensorflowInputVGGish.name: TensorflowInputVGGish
TensorflowInputVGGish.desc: This algorithm computes mel-bands with a particular parametrization specific to VGGish based models. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_TensorflowInputVGGish.html for more details.

TonalExtractor.name: TonalExtractor
TonalExtractor.desc: This algorithm computes tonal features for an audio signal Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_TonalExtractor.html for more details.

Description.1: the framesize for computing tonal features
Description.2: the hopsize for computing tonal features
Description.3: the tuning frequency of the input signal

TonicIndianArtMusic.name: TonicIndianArtMusic
TonicIndianArtMusic.desc: This algorithm estimates the tonic frequency of the lead artist in Indian art music. It uses multipitch representation of the audio signal (pitch salience) to compute a histogram using which the tonic is identified as one of its peak. The decision is made based on the distance between the prominent peaks, the classification is done using a decision tree. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_TonicIndianArtMusic.html for more details.

Description.1: salience function bin resolution [cents]
Description.2: the frame size for computing pitch saliecnce
Description.3: harmonic weighting parameter (weight decay ratio between two consequent harmonics, =1 for no decay)
Description.4: the hop size with which the pitch salience function was computed
Description.5: magnitude compression parameter (=0 for maximum compression, =1 for no compression)
Description.6: peak magnitude threshold (maximum allowed difference from the highest peak in dBs)
Description.7: the maximum allowed tonic frequency [Hz]
Description.8: the minimum allowed tonic frequency [Hz]
Description.9: number of considered hamonics
Description.10: number of top peaks of the salience function which should be considered for constructing histogram
Description.11: the reference frequency for Hertz to cent convertion [Hz], corresponding to the 0th cent bin
Description.12: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]

TriangularBands.name: TriangularBands
TriangularBands.desc: This algorithm computes energy in triangular frequency bands of a spectrum. The arbitrary number of overlapping bands can be specified. For each band the power-spectrum (mag-squared) is summed. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_TriangularBands.html for more details.

Description.0: the input spectrum (must be greater than size one)
Description.1: list of frequency ranges into which the spectrum is divided (these must be in ascending order and connot contain duplicates),each triangle is build as x(i-1)=0, x(i)=1, x(i+1)=0 over i, the resulting number of bands is size of input array - 2
Description.2: the size of the spectrum
Description.3: compute log-energies (log10 (1 + energy))
Description.4: spectrum bin weights to use for each triangular band: 'unit_max' to make each triangle vertex equal to 1, 'unit_sum' to make each triangle area equal to 1 summing the actual weights of spectrum bins, 'unit_area' to make each triangle area equal to 1 normalizing the weights of each triangle by its bandwidth
Description.5: the sampling rate of the audio signal [Hz]
Description.6: use magnitude or power spectrum
Description.7: type of weighting function for determining triangle area

TriangularBarkBands.name: TriangularBarkBands
TriangularBarkBands.desc:
This algorithm computes energy in the bark bands of a spectrum. It is different to the regular BarkBands algorithm in that is more configurable so that it can be used in the BFCC algorithm to produce output similar to Rastamat (http://www.ee.columbia.edu/ln/rosa/matlab/rastamat/)
			See the BFCC algorithm documentation for more information as to why you might want to choose this over Mel frequency analysis
			It is recommended that the input "spectrum" be calculated by the Spectrum algorithm. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_TriangularBarkBands.html for more details.

Description.1: an upper-bound limit for the frequencies to be included in the bands
Description.2: the size of the spectrum
Description.3: compute log-energies (log10 (1 + energy))
Description.4: a lower-bound limit for the frequencies to be included in the bands
Description.5: 'unit_max' makes the vertex of all the triangles equal to 1, 'unit_sum' makes the area of all the triangles equal to 1
Description.6: the number of output bands
Description.7: the sample rate
Description.8: 'power' to output squared units, 'magnitude' to keep it as the input
Description.9: type of weighting function for determining triangle area

Trimmer.name: Trimmer
Trimmer.desc:
This algorithm extracts a segment of an audio signal given its start and end times.
			Giving "startTime" greater than "endTime" will raise an exception. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_Trimmer.html for more details.

Description.1: check whether the specified time range for a slice fits the size of input signal (throw exception if not)
Description.2: the end time of the slice you want to extract [s]
Description.3: the sampling rate of the input audio signal [Hz]
Description.4: the start time of the slice you want to extract [s]

Tristimulus.name: Tristimulus
Tristimulus.desc: This algorithm calculates the tristimulus of a signal given its harmonic peaks. The tristimulus has been introduced as a timbre equivalent to the color attributes in the vision. Tristimulus measures the mixture of harmonics in a given sound, grouped into three sections. The first tristimulus measures the relative weight of the first harmonic; the second tristimulus measures the relative weight of the second, third, and fourth harmonics taken together; and the third tristimulus measures the relative weight of all the remaining harmonics. Check https://essentia.upf.edu/reference/std_Tristimulus.html for more details.

Description.0: the frequencies of the harmonic peaks ordered by frequency
Description.1: the magnitudes of the harmonic peaks ordered by frequency

val.tristimulus: a three-element vector that measures the mixture of harmonics of the given spectrum

TruePeakDetector.name: TruePeakDetector
TruePeakDetector.desc:
This algorithm implements a true-peak level meter for clipping detection. According to the ITU-R recommendations, true-peak values overcoming the full-scale range are potential sources of clipping in subsequent processes, such as within particular D/A converters or during sample-rate conversion.
			The ITU-R BS.1770-4[1] (by default) and the ITU-R BS.1770-2[2] signal-flows can be used. Go to the references for information about the differences.
			Only the peaks (if any) exceeding the configurable amplitude threshold are returned.
